MIND-047.thesis: While cognitive functions show some multiple realizability, AI reveals that architectural constraints limit which substrates can implement which functions. This challenges strong multiple realizability theses that treat implementation as irrelevant to function.
MIND-047.development: This limits multiple realizability. Functions can't be realized in just any substrate - architecture constrains realization. This weakens functionalism's independence from implementation.

MIND-048.title: Domain-General Principles Underlie Domain-Specific Competencies
source: WORK-011 (Essay 15: UG in Language and Music)
MIND-048.thesis: AI systems demonstrate that apparently domain-specific competencies (language, music) can arise from application of domain-general computational principles to different types of input. This supports a middle ground between pure modularity and pure domain-generality.
MIND-048.development: This reconciles modularity and domain-generality. The same general principles apply to different domains, producing domain-specific competence from domain-general architecture plus domain-specific input.

MIND-049.title: Consciousness Has Functional Role Absent in Current AI
MIND-049.thesis: AI systems demonstrate that many cognitive functions traditionally associated with consciousness (perception, reasoning, learning) can occur without consciousness. This reveals consciousness has a distinct functional role that current AI lacks - likely related to unified subjective experience and certain forms of self-monitoring.
MIND-049.development: This clarifies what consciousness does. Most cognitive functions don't need it, but some do. AI's success without consciousness reveals consciousness's actual role - not general intelligence but specific integration and self-monitoring.

MIND-050.title: AI Success Without Consciousness Reveals Consciousness is Not Required for Intelligence
MIND-050.thesis: The success of AI at intelligent tasks without consciousness demonstrates that consciousness is not necessary for intelligence per se, but may be necessary for specific types of cognitive integration or self-awareness.
MIND-050.development: This separates intelligence from consciousness. They can come apart - AI proves you can have intelligence without consciousness. This challenges views that equate the two.

MIND-051.title: Phenomenal Consciousness vs Functional Consciousness Distinction
MIND-051.thesis: AI reveals a crucial distinction between phenomenal consciousness (subjective experience) and functional consciousness (information integration, self-monitoring). AI can have functional analogs without phenomenal properties.
MIND-051.development: This clarifies Block's P-consciousness vs A-consciousness distinction through AI. AI can have access consciousness (functional) without phenomenal consciousness (subjective experience).

MIND-052.title: Self-Representation Requires Specific Architectural Features
source: WORK-011 (Essay 17: AI and Theories of Self)
MIND-052.thesis: AI systems reveal that genuine self-representation requires specific architectural features: recursive self-modeling, distinction between self and environment, and temporal continuity tracking. Not all intelligent systems automatically have these features.
MIND-052.development: This reveals what's needed for self-representation. AI shows self isn't automatic with intelligence - it requires specific architecture for recursive modeling and self-other distinction.

MIND-053.title: Narrative Self vs Minimal Self in AI Architecture
MIND-053.thesis: AI demonstrates the distinction between minimal self (basic subject of experience) and narrative self (autobiographical self-concept). These require different architectural implementations and can exist independently.
MIND-053.development: This uses AI to clarify the self. Minimal self (subject) and narrative self (autobiography) are architecturally distinct and separable - you can have one without the other.

MIND-054.title: Philosophical Skepticism Projects Internal Doubts onto External World
MIND-054.thesis: Philosophers' and obsessive-compulsives' supposed doubts about the external world are displaced, projected doubts about the internal world. Neither has genuine doubts about external reality, but both are doubtful about their internal psyche.
MIND-054.explanation: Provides psychoanalytic explanation of philosophical skepticism and reinterprets epistemological positions as projections of psychological conflict.

MIND-055.title: Intellectualism as Reaction to Dark Psychological Depths
MIND-055.thesis: The intellectualism of both philosophers and obsessive-compulsives is a reaction to and attempt to cloak their darkly retrograde psychological condition. They fancy themselves rational actors when they are actually driven by rage, narcissism, and fear.
MIND-055.explanation: Challenges rationalist self-conception and reveals it as defensive idealization masking irrational drives.

MIND-056.title: OCD and Philosophy Share Structural Isomorphism
MIND-056.thesis: There is deep structural isomorphism between philosophical methodology and OCD symptomatology: both involve compulsive doubt, retreat into abstraction, preoccupation with technicalities, projection of internal conflicts, and defense against engagement with reality.
MIND-056.explanation: Suggests fundamental reconceptualization of relationship between philosophical thought and psychopathology.

MIND-057.title: Cartesian Mind-Body Dualism as Defensive Idealization
MIND-057.thesis: The Lockean/Cartesian insistence on the non-existence of the unconscious and the claim that mind extends only as far as consciousness is a tendentious rationalization—a defensive idealization of the self as purely rational that denies the Nietzschean depths beneath the Cartesian veneer.
MIND-057.explanation: Psychoanalytic critique of Cartesian/Lockean philosophy of mind as motivated by defensive needs rather than truth.

MIND-058.title: Emotions as Reality-Alignment Indicators
MIND-058.statement: In histrionic, borderline, and dependent disorders, subjects have a fundamentally non-delusive grasp of reality, but their emotions are not appropriate to the reality thereby made available to them. By contrast, in psychotic disorders, the subject's very grasp of reality is scrambled, with emotions thus out of alignment with reality because reality itself is inaccessible.
MIND-058.justification: This distinction, articulated by Kuczynski (2012), explains the differential phenomenology of neurotic versus psychotic conditions. Neurotic disorders involve emotional mismatch with accurately perceived reality; psychotic disorders involve emotional response to fundamentally distorted reality-representation.
MIND-058.theoretical_significance: Distinguishes two ways mental illness can involve reality-emotion disconnect: emotional dysfunction versus reality-representation dysfunction

MIND-059.title: Intentionalism Defined
MIND-059.statement: Intentionalism is the doctrine that mental states cannot differ in phenomenal content unless they differ in representational content; phenomenology supervenes on representational content. This commits intentionalism to the view that phenomenal content intrinsically has representational content - nothing must be added (no contextualization, background knowledge, or ulterior factors) to secure this association.
MIND-059.justification: Just as aesthetic properties supervening on physical properties means nothing must be added to physical properties to secure the aesthetic properties, phenomenology supervening on representational content means the representational content is intrinsic to the phenomenology itself.
MIND-059.theoretical_significance: Clearly defines intentionalism's core commitment; establishes what must be proven false to refute intentionalism

MIND-060.title: Rules of Projection Versus Background Knowledge
MIND-060.statement: Rules of projection assign phenomenal contents (qualia) to disturbances of our sensory surfaces, while background knowledge assigns representational contents to those qualia. These have different functions but are part of a cooperative enterprise. Rules of projection do not assign representational contents directly to sensory disturbances.
MIND-060.justification: When neurosurgeons change Bob's auditory system from human to bat-like, the rule of projection changes - what used to phenomenally represent middle C now represents middle D. But it's background knowledge that determines what representational content corresponds to each phenomenal content under the operative rule of projection.
MIND-060.theoretical_significance: Distinguishes two distinct roles in perceptual processing; shows intentionalism conflates rule of projection with background knowledge

MIND-061.position: Consciousness can be stripped of emotional valences while retaining conceptual content

MIND-062.position: Emotional valence and conceptual knowledge are separable components of conscious experience

MIND-063.position: There is a barrier between the conscious and unconscious minds that can be more or less rigid

MIND-064.position: When the barrier between conscious and unconscious is too rigid, the conscious mind cannot draw on the power in the unconscious mind

MIND-065.position: Automatic writing involves 'letting' one's hand write 'all by itself'

MIND-066.position: Hallucinations brought about by religious ecstasies make the unseen presence literally visible

MIND-067.position: Mental states that mediate awareness of unseen presence are similar to those when conscious-unconscious boundary is relaxed (as in hypnosis or drug use)

MIND-068.position: Religious ecstasy involves effacement of self: one's ego disappears, being replaced by pure awareness of divinity

MIND-069.position: Content externalism has the absurd consequence that a thought's content has no effect on its psychological properties

MIND-070.position: Content externalism falsely implies that I cannot know I am thinking about Mary as opposed to Twin-Mary

MIND-071.position: When thoughts about external world are had via self-referential thoughts ('whatever caused this perception'), thoughts with different external referents can be subjectively identical and coincide in content

MIND-072.position: Self-ascriptive thoughts of the form 'I am now thinking that whatever caused this perception is F' cannot possibly be false

ACTION-001.title: Intentions as System-Level Judgments
ACTION-001.thesis: Intentions = judgments about how to consolidate psychological architecture. NOT desires.

ACTION-002.title: Values Distinct from Desires
ACTION-002.thesis: Values = beliefs about what consolidates psychological architecture. Values ≠ desires (though can interact).

ACTION-003.title: Free Acts as Value-Driven
ACTION-003.thesis: Free acts driven by values, NOT by second-order desires (contra Frankfurt). Second-order desires can be warped.

ACTION-004.title: Rational vs. Intelligent Distinction
ACTION-004.thesis: Rational = embodies due regard for interests. Intelligent = computational power. Irrational acts can be highly intelligent.

ACTION-005.title: Frankfurt's Analysis Insufficient
ACTION-005.thesis: Frankfurt right about higher-order states but wrong that second-order desires sufficient. Rationalization problem.

ACTION-006.title: Compatibilism About Free Will
ACTION-006.thesis: Free will is compatible with determinism. One acts freely when actions result from one's own desires and deliberations.

ACT-007.title: Psychopathy as Incapacity for Non-Pragmatic Agency
ACT-007.statement: Psychopaths use others but do not have relationships with them except of a purely pragmatic kind. To the extent a person is a psychopath, he cannot have meaningful relations with others. Psychopathic agency is purely instrumental, treating others as tools rather than as ends in themselves or as genuine relational partners.
ACT-007.justification: The definition of psychopathy includes lacking conscience and exhibiting callous disregard for others, manipulativeness, and deceitfulness. This constitutes fundamental incapacity for genuine relationship, reducing all interactions to instrumental utility.
ACT-007.theoretical_significance: Characterizes psychopathic agency as categorically distinct from normal agency in being incapable of non-instrumental relating; has implications for moral and legal responsibility

VALUE-001.title: Intrinsic Value and Self-Consolidation
VALUE-001.thesis: Intrinsically valuable = what consolidates one's agency. Not hedonistic.

VALUE-002.title: Instrumental vs Intrinsic Good
VALUE-002.thesis: Goodness divides into instrumental good (useful for goals) and intrinsic good (good in itself). Ethics concerns intrinsic goodness.

VALUE-003.title: Intrinsic Good vs Commendable
VALUE-003.thesis: Intrinsic goodness and praiseworthiness are distinct. Some intrinsically good things are not praiseworthy.

VALUE-004.title: Moral Responsibility Based on Intentions
VALUE-004.thesis: Praise/blame depends on intended outcome, not actual outcome.

VALUE-005.title: Against Emotivism
VALUE-005.thesis: Moral judgments are not merely expressions of emotion. They are genuine assertions with truth-values.

VALUE-006.title: Against Moral Relativism
VALUE-006.thesis: Moral relativism is false. There are objective moral truths.

VALUE-007.title: Against Kant's Categorical Imperative
VALUE-007.thesis: Kant's categorical imperative fails as a criterion for right action.

VALUE-008.title: Against Pure Hedonism
VALUE-008.thesis: Pleasure is not the only intrinsic good. Hedonism is false.

VALUE-009.title: Against Pure Utilitarianism
VALUE-009.thesis: Act utilitarianism is false. It violates rights and permits obviously wrong actions.

VALUE-010.title: Against Divine Command Theory
VALUE-010.thesis: Morality is not based on God's commands. Euthyphro dilemma refutes divine command theory.

VALUE-011.title: We Cannot Choose Our Values
VALUE-011.thesis: We cannot freely choose what we value. The idea of 'choosing one's own values' is incoherent.

VALUE-012.title: Law Must Be Based on Justice
VALUE-012.thesis: The purpose of law is to secure justice. Legal systems must be evaluated by whether they achieve justice.

VAL-014.position: One learns more from success than from failure (contra common wisdom)
VAL-014.source_section: One learns from adversity, not from failure

VAL-015.position: Each success opens up new and completely unforeseen vistas; each failure is nothing but a dead end from which nothing is learned
VAL-015.source_section: One learns from adversity, not from failure

VAL-016.position: One learns from adversity, not from failure
VAL-016.source_section: One learns from adversity, not from failure

VAL-017.position: Failure is the end-result of adversity that was not triumphed over; adversity and failure are distinct
VAL-017.source_section: One learns from adversity, not from failure

VAL-018.position: Everybody wants money, including those who claim to spurn it

VAL-019.position: Authentic religious sentiment does not require membership in an organized religion

VAL-020.position: Authentic religious sentiment requires a personal relationship with the divine

VAL-021.position: Religious people believe life to be meaningful and are therefore relatively adversity-tolerant

VAL-022.position: Religious sentiment makes people sane (when properly functioning)

MODAL-001.title: No Necessary A Posteriori Truths
MODAL-001.thesis: Apparent necessary a posteriori truths are either necessary-and-analytic or contingent-and-a-posteriori

MODAL-002.title: Epistemic and Metaphysical Necessity Coincide
MODAL-002.thesis: No genuine distinction between epistemic and metaphysical necessity

MODAL-003.title: Against Possible Worlds Semantics
MODAL-003.thesis: Possible worlds semantics for modality is either false or trivial. It doesn't explain what necessity and possibility are.

LANG-001.title: Semantics vs. Presemantics Distinction
LANG-001.thesis: Literal meaning must be distinguished from information through which one identifies that meaning

LANG-002.title: Universal Extensionality
LANG-002.thesis: ALL contexts extensional at semantic level. Co-referring terms intersubstitutable.

LANG-003.title: Direct Referentialism for Proper Names
LANG-003.thesis: Proper names are mere labels referring directly to objects

LANG-004.title: Direct Referentialism for Definite Descriptions
LANG-004.thesis: Descriptions refer directly but communicate Russellian propositions

LANG-005.title: Against Indirect Referentialism
LANG-005.thesis: Frege's sense/reference theory for descriptions is incoherent

LANG-006.title: Presemantic Implicature Theory
LANG-006.thesis: New category beyond Gricean post-semantic implicature

LANG-007.title: Definite Descriptions as Referring Expressions
LANG-007.thesis: Definite descriptions ('the phi') are referring terms, not quantificational. Always encode propositions of form 'a has phi'

LANG-008.title: Referential-Attributive Distinction as Pragmatic
LANG-008.thesis: Not semantic ambiguity. Both uses involve reference. Attributive: reference to entity in understood existence claim. Referential: ostensive.

LANG-009.title: Presupposition Not Assertion
LANG-009.thesis: Following Strawson: descriptions presuppose existence. Abortive (not false) when presupposition fails.

LANG-010.title: Against Contextualism
LANG-010.thesis: Rejects neo-Russellian move that context restricts quantifier domains. Violates Gricean principles.

LANG-011.title: Against Conventional Implicature Solution
LANG-011.thesis: D-sentences don't implicate object-dependent propositions via conventional implicature. Violates implicature principles.

LANG-012.title: Anaphoric Descriptions as Referential
LANG-012.thesis: Anaphoric descriptions refer to entities introduced by antecedents. Not bound variables.

LANG-013.title: Logical Form vs Semantics
LANG-013.thesis: Logical form (inferential structure) ≠ semantics (literal meaning). Same proposition can have multiple logical forms.

LANG-014.title: Logical Form vs Grammatical Form (Frege's Insight)
LANG-014.thesis: Logical form is not identical with grammatical form. What a sentence says is not always what its grammatical structure suggests.

LANG-015.title: Propositions as Abstract Objects
LANG-015.thesis: Propositions are abstract, mind-independent objects that exist outside space and time.

LANG-016.title: Truth as Correspondence
LANG-016.thesis: A proposition is true iff it corresponds to reality—if the world is as it says the world is.

LANG-017.title: Meaning is Not Mental
LANG-017.thesis: Linguistic meaning is not reducible to mental states or psychological facts.

LANG-018.title: Russell's Theory of Descriptions
LANG-018.thesis: Definite descriptions are not referring terms. 'The F is G' means 'Something uniquely is F, and any such thing is G.'

LANG-019.title: Frege's Sense/Reference Distinction Collapses into Russellianism
LANG-019.thesis: Frege's theory that definite descriptions have both sense and reference collapses into Russell's theory.

LANG-020.title: Against Fregean Intensional Contexts
LANG-020.thesis: Frege's distinction between extensional and intensional contexts is a failed epicycle.

LANG-021.title: Literal Meaning vs Cognitive Significance
LANG-021.thesis: Literal meaning (semantic content) must be distinguished from cognitive significance.

LANG-022.title: Semantic Externalism (Putnam's Insight)
LANG-022.thesis: Meanings of natural kind terms are partially determined by facts external to the speaker's mind.

LANG-023.title: Systematicity and Productivity of Language
LANG-023.thesis: Languages exhibit two fundamental properties: (1) Productivity - expressions can be combined into larger expressions, and (2) Systematicity - parts composing complex expressions can be re-arranged to form other expressions.
LANG-023.significance: Critical for argument that cognitive structure must be genuinely cognitive (not merely physiological)

LANG-024.title: Semantic Rules Are Ultimately Descriptive
LANG-024.thesis: Semantic rules describe what speakers mean/understand by expressions. They are not purely conventional stipulations independent of speaker practices. For 'red' to mean red just IS for speakers to mean/understand red by 'red'.
LANG-024.significance: Grounds meaning in speaker practices, not abstract rules
LANG-024.consistency: Theory of meaning connecting to use

LANG-025.title: Names as Concept-Laden Labels
LANG-025.thesis: Names are mere labels (non-descriptive), as Kripke argued, but labels 'pick up' descriptive information through how one learns their reference. Semantics (what expressions literally mean) differs from knowledge of semantics (how meaning is known), and this difference explains apparent descriptive content.
LANG-025.explanation: This reconciles Kripke's causal theory of reference with Frege's descriptive insights. Names are non-descriptive at the semantic level, but when one learns what a name refers to, the name becomes associated with descriptive features. Two co-referential names can convey different information depending on how their reference was learned, even though they have identical literal meanings.
key_distinctions: What expressions literally mean vs. what they mean to particular speakers
LANG-025.example: Though 'Hendricks is tall' and 'Revere is tall' have identical literal meaning (x is tall), they convey different information to someone who learned the names under different descriptions, explaining why one might not know the names co-refer.

LANG-026.title: Co-referential Names Can Differ in Meaning
LANG-026.thesis: 'Superman' and 'Clark Kent' differ in meaning despite co-referring. 'Superman is in the building' says that a certain property-set (superhuman strength, flight ability, etc.) is uniquely instantiated and any such instance is in the building. 'Clark Kent is in the building' says a different property-set (reporter, wears glasses, etc.) is uniquely instantiated.
LANG-026.explanation: This solves Frege's puzzle about informative identity statements. Co-referential names can express different propositions because they involve different uniquely instantiating property-sets, even though both sets are co-instantiated by the same individual.

challenges: Millian theories that deny meaning differences

LANG-027.title: Semantics-Pragmatics Distinction is Real
LANG-027.thesis: LLMs' demonstrated capabilities provide empirical support for classical theories of meaning, particularly the distinction between semantics (literal meaning) and pragmatics (communicated meaning), and the reality of compositional literal meaning.
LANG-027.evidence: LLMs systematically process novel sentences compositionally, distinguish literal from contextual meaning, without access to speaker intentions

LANG-028.title: Compositional Understanding Emerges from Statistical Learning
LANG-028.thesis: Compositional capabilities can emerge through statistical learning rather than requiring classical computational implementation. Both humans and AI develop compositional understanding through different but convergent paths.
LANG-028.key_insight: Humans learn from expression-to-situation patterns; AI from expression-to-expression patterns; both develop compositional understanding

LANG-029.title: Literal Meaning is Real but Emergent
LANG-029.thesis: Literal meaning is real rather than illusory, but emergent rather than primary. It develops through triangulation from contextual uses rather than being foundational to language.
LANG-029.synthesis: Preserves classical insights while acknowledging critics' valid points about context dependence

LANG-030.title: Grammar and Logic Are Aligned
LANG-030.thesis: LLMs' ability to make correct inferences without FOL-style logical forms suggests grammatical structure itself guides valid reasoning. Perceived misalignment between grammatical and logical form may be artifact of our chosen formal systems rather than feature of language itself.
LANG-030.evidence: LLMs process quantified expressions correctly without translating to FOL, positing hidden logical form, or being misled by surface grammar

LANG-031.title: Logical Form is Cognitively Inert
LANG-031.thesis: Traditional logical form is cognitively inert: people reason without it, LLMs function without it, it plays no role in actual inference. Logical form is constructed rather than discovered, follows rather than guides comprehension, and is system-relative rather than unique.
LANG-031.implication: Grammar reliably guides inference, encodes logical relationships, supports sophisticated reasoning—without need for separate logical form

LANG-032.title: Universal Grammar as Neural Architecture
LANG-032.thesis: Chomskyan insights about linguistic universals can be reconciled with connectionism by understanding UG as feature of neural architecture rather than set of explicit rules. UG constraints operate through architectural properties of neural networks rather than explicit rule-following.
LANG-032.synthesis: Preserves Chomsky's explanatory insights while aligning with connectionist implementation

LANG-033.title: AI Vindicates Semantics-Pragmatics Distinction
source: WORK-011 (Essay 6: AI Vindicates Classical Theories of Meaning)
LANG-033.thesis: Large language models demonstrate a clear distinction between semantic content (literal meaning) and pragmatic interpretation (context-dependent meaning). The success of LLMs requires maintaining this distinction, vindicating classical theories of meaning against pragmatist attempts to collapse semantics into pragmatics.
LANG-033.development: This vindicates classical semantics against post-modern pragmatism. LLMs must distinguish literal meaning from pragmatic interpretation, proving the distinction is real and necessary.

LANG-034.title: Literal Meaning is Computationally Prior to Pragmatic Interpretation
LANG-034.thesis: AI systems must compute literal semantic content before applying pragmatic adjustments. This computational priority reveals that semantics is foundational and pragmatics is derivative, supporting classical over post-modern theories of meaning.
LANG-034.development: This shows the order of processing - semantics first, then pragmatics. LLMs must compute literal meaning before context effects, proving semantics is not reducible to pragmatics.

LANG-035.title: Context-Independence of Core Semantics
LANG-035.thesis: LLMs demonstrate that core semantic content can be represented context-independently and then applied across contexts. This vindicates the classical view that meaning has a stable core that pragmatic factors modulate rather than wholly constitute.
LANG-035.development: This defends stable meaning against radical contextualism. Words have core meanings independent of context, which context then modulates. AI proves meanings aren't wholly context-dependent.

LANG-036.title: AI Vindicates Syntax-Semantics Interface
LANG-036.thesis: Large language models demonstrate that grammatical structure (syntax) and meaning (semantics) are distinct but systematically related. The success of LLMs requires explicit representation of this interface, vindicating classical grammatical theory against attempts to reduce one to the other.
LANG-036.development: This vindicates the syntax-semantics distinction. AI shows they're different but related - you can't reduce syntax to semantics or vice versa. Both are necessary.

LANG-037.title: Syntactic Structure Constrains Semantic Interpretation
LANG-037.thesis: AI language systems reveal that syntactic structure constrains possible semantic interpretations. This supports the classical view that grammar is not arbitrary convention but reflects systematic constraints on meaning composition.
LANG-037.development: This shows syntax isn't arbitrary - it constrains meaning. The way words combine grammatically determines possible meanings, proving grammar reflects semantic structure.

LANG-038.title: Compositional Semantics Requires Syntactic Structure
LANG-038.thesis: The ability of LLMs to understand novel sentences demonstrates that semantic interpretation is compositional - the meaning of complex expressions derives systematically from their parts and syntactic structure. This requires and vindicates traditional compositional semantic theories.
LANG-038.development: This vindicates compositionality. LLMs understand novel sentences by composing meanings from parts according to syntax, proving meaning is compositional as Frege claimed.

LANG-039.title: Grammar and Logic are Fundamentally Aligned
LANG-039.thesis: AI language systems demonstrate that grammatical structure and logical form are fundamentally aligned - grammatical categories and relations correspond to logical types and operations. This alignment is not accidental but reflects deep unity of form in human cognition.
LANG-039.development: This is a major thesis - grammar and logic align because both reflect underlying cognitive structure. AI proves this by using grammar to do logic. The alignment is deep and necessary, not superficial.

LANG-040.title: Universal Grammar Can Be Implemented Subsymbolically
LANG-040.thesis: AI demonstrates that universal grammar principles can be implemented through subsymbolic connectionist architectures rather than requiring explicit symbolic rules. The functional role of UG is preserved even if implementation differs from classical theory.
LANG-040.development: This reconciles Chomsky with connectionism. UG exists and is innate, but it's implemented as connection weights not explicit rules. Function is preserved with different implementation.

LANG-041.title: Universal Grammar Principles Extend to Music
source: WORK-011 (Essay 15: UG in Language and Music)
LANG-041.thesis: AI analysis reveals that the computational principles underlying universal grammar in language also apply to music cognition. Both domains share abstract structural principles about hierarchical organization and rule-governed combination.
LANG-041.development: This extends UG beyond language. The same abstract principles govern both language and music, suggesting they're domain-general principles that apply to different inputs.

LANG-045.title: Presupposition Versus Assertion in Perceptual Reports
LANG-045.statement: When sensations are property-indeterminate (as in the tie shop), one cannot assert 'the tie is maroon' based on sensation alone. One might respond that the sensation presupposes rather than asserts a determinacy. But this conflates epistemology with semantics - the point is that sensation doesn't tell you which property obtains, not that it pragmatically presupposes one.
LANG-045.justification: The response treating sensations as presupposing rather than asserting property-determinacy doesn't address the epistemic point. Until background knowledge is added, the sensation simply doesn't determine which of several incompatible properties the object has.
LANG-045.theoretical_significance: Clarifies distinction between semantic presupposition and epistemic determination; blocks objection to indeterminacy argument

LANG-046.title: 'Some' Presupposes Rather Than Asserts Existence
LANG-046.statement: 'Some phi is a psi' is not an existence-claim. It does not assert that there exists at least one phi that is also a psi. Rather, it merely presupposes that there is at least one phi. This concerns literal meaning (semantics), not what is conveyed by implicature.
LANG-046.justification: 'There is at least one diamond on the table, and at least one such diamond is extremely valuable' explicitly says there is at least one diamond. But 'Some of the diamonds on the table are extremely valuable' doesn't say this - it presupposes it. If it's in question whether there are any diamonds, the first utterance is appropriate but the second is not, because the second presupposes an answer to an unanswered question.
LANG-046.theoretical_significance: Challenges standard logical semantics treating 'some' as existential quantifier; distinguishes presupposition from assertion in quantified statements

LANG-047.title: 'All' is Incompatible With 'Some'
LANG-047.statement: 'All phi's are psi's' is incompatible with 'some phi's are psi's.' The former entails the negation of the latter and thus isn't compatible with it. This concerns literal meaning, not pragmatic implicature.
LANG-047.justification: If 'some' meant 'at least one (and possibly all)' as standard logic claims, then 'all' would be compatible with 'some.' But the natural language use shows these are incompatible - saying all phi's are psi's excludes that only some are.
LANG-047.theoretical_significance: Refutes standard logical treatment of quantifiers where universal quantification entails existential; shows 'some' means 'some but not all'

LANG-048.title: Numerals Express Exact Quantities
LANG-048.statement: For any numeral n, 'n phi's are psi's' is to the effect that exactly n phi's are psi's. 'Five elephants can dance' means exactly five elephants can dance, not 'at least five.' If six elephants can dance, the statement 'five elephants can dance' is literally false, not merely misleading.
LANG-048.justification: If 'five' meant 'at least five,' then 'Brown owes precisely $10,000' would mean 'Brown owes precisely at least $10,000,' which is nonsensical. The modifier 'precisely' serves to confine attention to literal meaning, showing '10,000' already means exactly 10,000. The same applies to all numerals.
LANG-048.theoretical_significance: Refutes standard linguistic analysis treating numerals as lower bounds; shows numerals have exact rather than minimal readings

LANG-049.title: Incompatibility of Different Numeral Statements
LANG-049.statement: If m≠n, 'm phi's are psi's' is incompatible with 'n phi's are psi's.' 'Ten elephants can dance' is incompatible with 'five elephants can dance.' This is an immediate consequence of numerals expressing exact quantities.
LANG-049.justification: Given that 'five' means exactly five (not at least five), and 'ten' means exactly ten, these claims are logically incompatible. The argument 'Given that Smith has seven cars, he has an odd number of cars' is valid only if 'seven' means exactly seven; if it meant 'at least seven,' the argument would be invalid.
LANG-049.theoretical_significance: Establishes logical relationships between numeral statements contrary to standard semantics; shows incompatibility where standard logic sees entailment

LANG-050.title: Numerals as Substantives Versus Adjectives
LANG-050.statement: In '5 + 5 = 10,' numerals function as substantives (nouns), synonymous with 'the number 5' and 'the number 10.' In '5 things plus 5 other things add up to exactly 10 things,' the same numerals function as adjectives. Despite this syntactic difference, the expressions have extremely similar meanings, which would be impossible if numerals meant 'at least n.'
LANG-050.justification: '5 + 5 = 10' is indisputably to the effect that 5 + 5 = exactly 10. Given the similarity in meaning between this and '5 things plus 5 other things add up to exactly 10 things,' the latter must also involve 'exactly' readings. But if '5' meant 'at least five,' the similarity would be lost.
LANG-050.theoretical_significance: Shows numeral semantics must be preserved across syntactic categories; provides independent argument for exact reading of numerals

LANG-051.title: Sentence Truth-Conditions Versus Proposition Truth-Conditions
LANG-051.statement: The logical properties of propositions aren't always in lockstep with those of the sentences (or sentence-tokens) that express them. For definite descriptions with Strawson-type semantics, the sentence 'that phi is psi' has different truth-conditions from the proposition it expresses in context.
LANG-051.justification: According to Strawson's view, when O is uniquely salient, an utterance of 'that phi is psi' expresses a proposition true exactly if O has psi. But the utterance itself is true exactly if there is exactly one salient individual and that individual has psi. The proposition is true/false simpliciter; the sentence is true/false relative to context.
LANG-051.theoretical_significance: Distinguishes sentence-level from proposition-level semantic properties; shows context-sensitivity requires this distinction

LANG-052.title: Response Adequacy Test for Existence Claims
LANG-052.statement: If asked 'do any felines exist?', responding '(A) Yes. There exists at least one feline; moreover, at least one feline is ferocious' is completely non-defective, but responding '(B) some felines are ferocious' is defective. This shows (B) presupposes rather than asserts existence, distinguishing it from (A).
LANG-052.justification: The question directly asks about existence. An adequate answer must assert existence (A does this). (B) is defective because it presupposes what the question asks about rather than answering the question. This confirms 'some' presupposes rather than asserts existence.
LANG-052.theoretical_significance: Provides dialogue-based test for distinguishing presupposition from assertion; shows question-answer compatibility reveals semantic structure

LANG-053.title: Anti-Gricean Analysis of Quantifiers and Numerals
LANG-053.statement: The correct analysis of 'some,' 'all,' and numerals concerns literal meaning (semantics), not conversational implicature. 'Some' means 'some but not all' at the level of semantics, not just by Gricean implicature. Similarly, 'five' means 'exactly five' semantically, not 'at least five' with an implicature of exactness.
LANG-053.justification: Gricean analysis would claim 'some' semantically means 'at least one (possibly all)' but implicates 'not all.' But the presupposition tests and incompatibility arguments show these are semantic, not pragmatic, features. If they were mere implicatures, they would be cancelable and wouldn't affect literal truth-conditions.
LANG-053.chapter: Throughout - explicit rejection of implicature analysis
LANG-053.theoretical_significance: Challenges dominant Gricean framework treating scalar implicatures as pragmatic; argues for richer semantic content in natural language quantifiers

LANG-055.position: There are different ways of picking out a number: canonical (using usual numerical notation) vs. non-canonical descriptions

LANG-056.position: Taken in isolation, a given action can be interpreted as compliance with any of a plurality of incompatible rules, but independent evidence disambiguates

LANG-057.position: Wittgenstein's 'paradox' collapses into the trivial point that erroneous hypotheses may be compatible with artificially restricted data sets

LANG-058.position: Quine's 'indeterminacy of translation' thesis only appears true if one considers artificially constricted data-sets

LANG-059.position: Sorites paradoxes are solved by replacing binary characterizations with comparatives plus contextually supplied benchmarks

LANG-060.position: Vague terms like 'heap', 'rich', 'part of cloud' implicitly invoke contextual benchmarks; n+1 items are always 'more' than n items relative to some standard

LANG-061.position: 'Superman is in the building' says that a certain property-set (being superhumanly strong, able to fly, etc.) is uniquely instantiated and in the building

LANG-062.position: Names are non-descriptive mere labels (Kripke is right about this)

LANG-063.position: Even mere labels 'pick up' descriptive information; one doesn't learn what a name refers to in a vacuum

LANG-064.position: There is semantics (what expressions literally mean) and there is knowledge of semantics; how one knows literal meaning may affect what sentences mean to that person

LANG-065.position: Two utterances with the same literal meaning may convey very different bodies of information to those who know that literal meaning

PRAG-001.title: Cancelability Test
PRAG-001.thesis: Conversational implicatures always cancelable. Existence presuppositions not cancelable. Therefore not conversational implicature.

PRAG-002.title: Conventional Implicature Constraint
PRAG-002.thesis: Conventional implicature doesn't obscure truth-conditions. Adds 'tone' but never makes synonyms differ in truth-conditions.

PRAG-003.title: Function of 'Exactly,' 'Precisely,' 'Literally' Modifiers
PRAG-003.statement: Expressions like 'exactly,' 'precisely,' and 'literally' have the semantic function of confining the auditor's attention to literal meaning - telling the auditor not to draw inferences beyond what is literally affirmed. These modifiers reveal what expressions mean literally by blocking pragmatic enrichment.
PRAG-003.justification: In dialogue, when Jones says 'He has a billion dollars' and then clarifies 'He literally has a billion dollars,' the second utterance confirms the first is to be taken literally. Similarly, 'Brown owes precisely $10,000' indicates the amount is exact. If 'exactly' and 'precisely' already meant 'at least,' these modifiers would be redundant or nonsensical.
PRAG-003.theoretical_significance: Identifies linguistic devices for distinguishing semantic from pragmatic content; provides method for determining literal meanings

LOGIC-001.title: Analytic Truth Defined by Content Alone
LOGIC-001.thesis: Analytic truths hold entirely in virtue of own content. Given only what they say, could not fail to be true.

LOGIC-002.title: Tautologies are NOT Analytic Truths
LOGIC-002.thesis: Tautologies = definitional truths about word usage (empirical). No analytic truths are tautologies.

LOGIC-003.title: All Mathematical Truths are Analytic
LOGIC-003.thesis: Every mathematical truth is analytic. Mathematical knowledge = non-empirical knowledge of conceptual relations.

LOGIC-004.title: Not All Analytic Truths are Mathematical
LOGIC-004.thesis: Philosophy has its own domain of analytic truths. Example: 'All math truths are analytic' is analytic but philosophical.

LOGIC-005.title: Analytic Truth vs. Formal Truth Distinction
LOGIC-005.thesis: Analytic truth ≠ formal truth. Formally true = recursively definable. Math truths analytic but not formal.

LOGIC-006.title: Incompleteness as Non-Recursive-Definability
LOGIC-006.thesis: Incomplete = no recursive definition. Most scientifically important statement-sets incomplete.

LOGIC-007.title: Sorites Vagueness Admitted
LOGIC-007.thesis: The sorites paradox is genuine and shows that vague predicates lack sharp boundaries. There are borderline cases where no determinate fact makes a predicate apply or not apply.
LOGIC-007.explanation: Unlike many paradoxes in this collection, Kuczynski accepts the sorites as revealing genuine vagueness in natural language. This acknowledges limits of classical logic when applied to vague predicates.

LOGIC-008.title: Logic is Incomplete (More General than Gödel)
LOGIC-008.thesis: Class of all logics not itself recursively definable. Logic is incomplete. More general than Gödel's result.

LOGIC-009.title: Logic as Recursively Defined Statement-Set
LOGIC-009.thesis: A logic = recursively defined statement-set = axiomatic system

LOGIC-010.title: Logicism Defended (Frege's Project)
LOGIC-010.thesis: Arithmetic is reducible to logic. Mathematical truths are logical truths.

LOGIC-011.title: Classical Logic as Formalization Not Discovery
LOGIC-011.thesis: Classical logic is fundamentally inadequate as a tool for reasoning because it requires more intelligence to recognize that an inference instantiates a logical law than to recognize the validity of the inference directly. Logic organizes existing knowledge about entailment but cannot generate new knowledge about entailment relationships.
LOGIC-011.key_argument: Recognizing inference validity is precondition for knowing there exists logical law validating it
LOGIC-011.historical_note: When this inadequacy became apparent, logicians tried to redefine logic as revealing mathematical foundations (Russell/Whitehead), but Gödel proved arithmetic isn't recursively definable

LOGIC-012.title: Performance vs. Competence-Demanding Inferences
LOGIC-012.thesis: Two fundamentally different types of inferential challenges exist: (1) Performance-demanding (straining computational/memory resources), (2) Competence-demanding (requiring genuine insight). Classical logic can only assist with the former.

LOGIC-013.title: System L: AI-Based Discovery Logic
LOGIC-013.thesis: A radically different logical system exists in AI that actually helps reasoning through: (1) semantic networks representing concepts as relationship nodes, (2) meta-reasoning patterns generating new inferences, (3) defeasible reasoning allowing provisional inferences.
LOGIC-013.implementation: Can be given precise mathematical definition with formalized protocols

LOGIC-014.title: Discovery-Justification Distinction in Logic
LOGIC-014.thesis: System L maintains crucial distinction between discovery procedures (can use any methods including inductive/analogical) and verification procedures (must employ deductive methods in deductive domains). Avoids psychologism while enabling reasoning assistance.
LOGIC-014.key_principle: Search procedures can use any helpful methods; verification must meet domain-appropriate standards

LOGIC-015.title: AI Logic as Ampliative vs. Classical Logic as Transformative
LOGIC-015.thesis: AI-logic is inherently ampliative (generating genuinely new knowledge), while classical logic is purely transformative (rearranging existing knowledge). Only AI-logic can serve as genuine discovery tool.
LOGIC-015.fundamental_distinctions: Ampliative power, organic process modeling, flexible implementation, reflexivity handling

LOGIC-016.title: Classical Logic Fails as a Tool for Reasoning
source: WORK-011 (Essay 1: AI Logic vs. Classical Logic - Part 1)
LOGIC-016.thesis: Classical logic fundamentally fails as a tool for reasoning because recognizing that an inference instantiates a logical law requires more intelligence than recognizing the validity of the inference directly. Logic organizes existing knowledge about entailment but cannot generate new knowledge.
LOGIC-016.development: This is a fundamental critique of classical logic's role. It explains why formal logic cannot help with actual reasoning - the formalization requires more intelligence than the reasoning itself. This is central to Kuczynski's logic program.

LOGIC-017.title: Performance-Demanding vs Competence-Demanding Inferences Distinction
LOGIC-017.thesis: Inferential challenges divide into performance-demanding (requiring computational/memory resources) and competence-demanding (requiring genuine insight). Classical logic can only assist with the former, not the latter - the very kind that most need logical assistance.
LOGIC-017.development: This distinction is crucial for understanding why classical logic fails. Performance problems can be solved with more computational power, but competence problems require insight that formalization cannot provide.

LOGIC-018.title: Gödel's Incompleteness Refutes Logic as Mathematical Foundation
source: WORK-011 (Essay 1 - Part 1, response to logicist project)
LOGIC-018.thesis: Gödel's demonstration that not even arithmetic is recursively definable makes the reduction of mathematics to logic impossible in principle. Logic cannot both justify and generate mathematical knowledge as was hoped.
LOGIC-018.development: This connects Gödel's technical results to the philosophical failure of logicism. Mathematics cannot be reduced to logic, destroying one major justification for classical logic.

LOGIC-019.title: System L: Discovery Logic via AI
LOGIC-019.thesis: A new logical system (System L) embodied in certain AI forms represents a decisive break from classical logic. It employs semantic networks, meta-reasoning patterns, and defeasible reasoning to actually help with competence-demanding inferences rather than merely cataloging known-valid inferences.
LOGIC-019.development: This is Kuczynski's positive proposal for logic. System L is not just another formal system but a fundamentally different approach that actually assists reasoning. It's implemented in AI, showing it works in practice.

LOGIC-020.title: Semantic Networks Enable Competence-Level Reasoning
source: WORK-011 (Essay 1 - Part 2, first mechanism of System L)
LOGIC-020.thesis: System L represents concepts as nodes in a vast web of relationships capturing not just formal logical connections but probabilistic associations, causal links, and analogical mappings. This enables insight-level reasoning that formal logic cannot provide.
LOGIC-020.development: This describes the first key mechanism of System L - how semantic networks enable genuine reasoning assistance by capturing relationships that formal syntax cannot represent.

LOGIC-021.title: Meta-Reasoning Patterns Generate New Inferences
LOGIC-021.thesis: System L uses higher-order templates for generating new inferences that go beyond simple deductive rules. Example template: 'If capability X requires mechanism Y, and mechanism Y can malfunction in way Z, then X implies the potential for Z-type malfunctions.'
LOGIC-021.development: This describes the second mechanism - meta-reasoning patterns that generate new inferences. These are not deductive rules but heuristic templates that guide discovery.

LOGIC-022.title: Defeasible Reasoning Mirrors Actual Human Reasoning
LOGIC-022.thesis: Incorporating defeasible reasoning - provisional inferences that can be revised in light of new information - better mirrors actual human reasoning and provides more practical utility than classical logic's requirement for absolute certainty.
LOGIC-022.development: The third mechanism of System L - defeasible reasoning. Real reasoning is revisable, not monotonic. System L captures this while classical logic cannot.

LOGIC-023.title: Grammatical Structure Guides Logical Inference
LOGIC-023.thesis: LLMs successfully perform logical reasoning by following grammatical structure, demonstrating that surface grammar encodes logical relationships. This vindicates the traditional view that grammatical form reveals logical form.
LOGIC-023.development: This shows that grammar and logic are not arbitrary - grammatical structure guides logical inference. AI's success at reasoning through grammar demonstrates this empirically.

LOGIC-024.title: Entailment Defined as Logical Consequence
LOGIC-024.thesis: P entails Q if and only if Q is a logical consequence of P. If P entails Q and P is true, then Q must be true and may be legitimately inferred from P.
LOGIC-024.justification: Entailment is the relation that licenses deductive inference. It holds when the truth of the premises necessitates the truth of the conclusion by logical form alone.
LOGIC-024.theoretical_significance: Provides the fundamental definition of deductive logical relations

LOGIC-025.title: Confirmation Defined as Probability-Increase
LOGIC-025.thesis: P confirms Q if and only if P, supposing it true, increases the likelihood that Q is true. Confirmation does not by itself license inference from P to Q.
LOGIC-025.justification: Confirmation is a weaker relation than entailment. P can confirm Q while also confirming not-Q, or while making Q more probable without making it probable.
LOGIC-025.theoretical_significance: Distinguishes probabilistic support from deductive entailment, clarifying the logic of inductive inference

LOGIC-026.title: Conditions for Legitimate Inductive Inference
LOGIC-026.thesis: Q may legitimately be inferred from P if and only if: (a) the supposition that P is true and Q is false has fewer unexplainable consequences than the supposition that P and Q are both true, AND (b) the supposition that P is true has fewer unexplainable consequences than the supposition that P is false.
LOGIC-026.justification: Legitimate induction requires that accepting Q given P reduces overall anomalies and that P itself is well-supported. Mere confirmation is insufficient for inference.
LOGIC-026.theoretical_significance: Provides precise conditions for rational inductive inference based on anomaly-elimination

LOGIC-027.title: Four Principles: Entailment vs. Confirmation
LOGIC-027.thesis: Four logical principles hold: (i) Entailment is transitive; (ii) Confirmation is not transitive; (iii) Entailment is monotonic; (iv) Confirmation is non-monotonic. These differences show entailment and confirmation are fundamentally different relations.
LOGIC-027.justification: If P entails Q and Q entails R, then P entails R (transitivity). But P confirming Q and Q confirming R does not ensure P confirms R. Adding information can defeat confirmation but not entailment.
LOGIC-027.theoretical_significance: Establishes the formal logical differences between deductive and inductive relations

LOGIC-028.title: Entailment Not Maximal Confirmation
LOGIC-028.thesis: Entailment is not maximal confirmation. Entailment is a logical notion concerning what is counterlogical; confirmation is an explanatory notion concerning what is counterexplanatory.
LOGIC-028.justification: For P to entail Q is for P-and-not-Q to be counterlogical (structurally impossible). For P to confirm Q is for P-and-not-Q to be counterexplanatory (having more unexplainable consequences). These are distinct concepts.
LOGIC-028.theoretical_significance: Clarifies the conceptual distinction between logical and explanatory relations

LOGIC-029.title: Confirmation-Relations Non-Objectual in Nature
LOGIC-029.thesis: Confirmation relations, though not themselves causal relations, sometimes hold in virtue of causal relations. But confirmation relates propositions, not objects or events.
LOGIC-029.justification: That smoking confirms high blood pressure holds because smoking tends to cause high blood pressure. But neither the proposition nor the confirmation relation is itself a cause or effect.
LOGIC-029.theoretical_significance: Clarifies the ontological status of confirmation as a propositional rather than causal relation

LOGIC-030.title: The Counterfactual Analysis of Causality (CAC) Is False
LOGIC-030.thesis: The Counterfactual Analysis of Causality - the view that 'e caused e*' means 'if e hadn't happened, e* wouldn't have happened' - is both extensionally and intensionally false.
LOGIC-030.justification: Extensionally false: CAC fails when circumstances program for e*'s occurrence (redundant causation). Intensionally false: counterfactual knowledge derives from causal knowledge, not vice versa.
LOGIC-030.theoretical_significance: Decisively rejects major contemporary analysis of causation, showing causation is more fundamental than counterfactuals

LOGIC-036.title: Generalization from Color to All Perceivable Properties
LOGIC-036.statement: The argument about color-indeterminacy of sensations under non-standard lighting conditions generalizes to any perceivable property P. Distance perception provides the key example: when viewing through variable magnification (microscope/telescope goggles), visual sensations are distance- and size-indeterminate until background knowledge establishes the correspondence rule.
LOGIC-036.justification: When you just see that a tree is 80 feet away, background information is at work - you take for granted the tree isn't 10,000 feet tall. With variable magnification goggles, the same sensation could represent either a 10-foot object 100 feet away or a 10,000-foot object ten miles away. Only learning the correspondence rule makes sensations determinate.
LOGIC-036.theoretical_significance: Extends property-indeterminacy argument from color to spatial properties and by implication all perceivable properties; shows indeterminacy is universal feature of raw sensation

LOGIC-037.title: Standard Logical Quantifier Semantics Conflicts With Natural Language
LOGIC-037.statement: Most contemporary logicians and philosophers assume or explicitly state that each of the five points (about 'some,' 'all,' and numerals) is false, and much of what they say crumbles unless they're right. But the points are correct, showing standard logical semantics for quantifiers and numerals diverges from natural language meanings.
LOGIC-037.justification: Standard logic treats 'some' as existential quantifier (at least one, possibly all), treats 'all phi's' as compatible with 'some phi's,' and treats numerals as lower bounds. But arguments from presupposition, incompatibility, and 'exactly/precisely' modifiers show these analyses are false to natural language.
LOGIC-037.theoretical_significance: Identifies systematic divergence between logical formalism and natural language; challenges whether standard logical notation accurately captures natural language semantics

LOGIC-038.title: Validity of Argument Reveals Semantic Content
LOGIC-038.statement: The argument 'Given that Smith has seven cars, he has an odd number of cars' is valid. This reveals that 'seven' means exactly seven, not 'at least seven,' since if 'seven' meant 'at least seven,' the argument would be invalid (as 'at least seven' is compatible with even numbers).
LOGIC-038.justification: Validity preservation requires that 'seven' have exact meaning. There's no independent support for claiming the argument is valid only at the level of pragmatic implicature while invalid semantically. The most natural explanation is that 'seven' semantically means exactly seven.
LOGIC-038.theoretical_significance: Uses logical validity as diagnostic for semantic content; shows arithmetical reasoning presupposes exact numeral meanings

LOGIC-039.position: 'True of itself' when meaningful abbreviates some non-reflexive construction; when it doesn't, 'self' is an undefined pronoun (free variable)

LOGIC-040.position: It is propositions (underlying meanings), not words per se, that are true or false

LOGIC-041.position: If h is synonymous with 'the referent of h+1', then h is defined in terms of an expression itself defined in terms of h, and h consequently has no referent

LOGIC-042.position: There is no recursive definition of the class of recursive definitions (Kuczynski's Recursion Paradox)

LOGIC-043.position: There is no formal characterization of formal truth (corollary of Recursion Paradox)

LOGIC-044.position: Everything can be automated except for automation itself (Automation Paradox)

METHOD-001.title: Multiple Independent Arguments Strategy
METHOD-001.thesis: Major conclusions supported by multiple independent arguments

METHOD-002.title: Charitable Interpretation Principle
METHOD-002.thesis: Consider strongest versions of opposing views before critique

METHOD-003.title: Concrete Examples Before Abstract Principles
METHOD-003.thesis: Use concrete examples to motivate and illustrate abstract philosophical positions

METHOD-004.title: Pragmatics-Constrained Semantics
METHOD-004.thesis: Semantic theories must respect known pragmatic principles. Can't just assert 'implicature explains it' without checking constraints.

METH-007.title: AI Construction Tests Cognitive Theories Empirically
METH-007.thesis: The requirement that cognitive theories be implementable in functioning AI systems provides an empirical constraint: theories that cannot generate working systems are falsified. This connects abstract theorizing to concrete engineering requirements.
METH-007.development: This articulates the key methodological innovation - theories must work in practice. If you can't build working AI from your theory, your theory is wrong. This makes philosophy empirical.

METH-008.title: Formalization Requires Generative Not Just Organizational Adequacy
METH-008.thesis: AI reveals that adequate formalization requires not just organizing existing knowledge but generating new valid instances. A formalization is adequate only if it can generate the full range of valid cases, not merely classify them post hoc.
METH-008.development: This raises the bar for formalization. It's not enough to organize known cases - you must be able to generate new cases. This is a stronger test that many formalizations fail.

METH-009.title: Generative Tests Reveal Hidden Inadequacies in Formalizations
METH-009.thesis: Testing whether a formalization can generate valid new instances (as AI systems must) reveals inadequacies invisible to purely organizational approaches. Many traditional formalizations fail this stronger generative test.
METH-009.development: This explains why generative testing matters - it catches problems organizational testing misses. A formalization might organize existing cases but fail to generate new ones, revealing it's incomplete.

METH-010.title: No Such Thing as Enumerative Induction
METH-010.thesis: There is no such thing as enumerative induction (inferring 'all Fs are Gs' from 'all observed Fs are Gs'). What appears to be enumerative induction always involves implicit appeal to Inference to the Best Explanation (IBE).
METH-010.justification: Knowing all observed ravens are black doesn't license inferring unobserved ravens are black unless one believes some mechanism (causal or otherwise) connects being a raven with being black. Without such a mechanism, the inference is irrational.
METH-010.theoretical_significance: Solves Hume's problem of induction by showing genuine induction is IBE, not enumeration

METH-011.title: Discontinuity-Elimination the Essence of Explanation
METH-011.thesis: To explain is to eliminate discontinuities. A correct scientific hypothesis eliminates anomalies by showing how apparently disconnected facts are part of continuous causal processes.
METH-011.justification: Seeing a ball enter and exit an opaque tunnel leaves a discontinuity. The hypothesis that it's the same ball continuing to roll eliminates the discontinuity, making the emergence continuous with prior state.
METH-011.theoretical_significance: Provides unified account of explanation across all sciences as continuity-restoration

METH-012.title: Inductive Knowledge as Knowledge of Continuities
METH-012.thesis: Inductive knowledge is knowledge of continuities between continuities. Valid induction extends known continuous causal processes to unobserved cases by identifying higher-order patterns of continuity.
METH-012.justification: We infer unobserved cases are like observed ones when we recognize both as instances of a continuous causal process. Induction finds continuities at multiple levels of description.
METH-012.theoretical_significance: Grounds induction in pattern-recognition of multi-level causal continuity rather than mere enumeration

METH-013.title: IBE Justified by Continuity-Completion
METH-013.thesis: Inference to the Best Explanation (IBE) is justified because it completes causal continuities. A hypothesis is justified to the extent it fills gaps in causal sequences, eliminating discontinuities in the data.
METH-013.justification: Good IBEs posit entities or processes that make previously anomalous data continuous with surrounding known facts. Justification comes from improved causal continuity, not mere pattern-fitting.
METH-013.theoretical_significance: Provides epistemological justification for IBE grounded in continuity rather than mere explanatory power

METH-014.title: Measurement Distinct from Enumeration
METH-014.thesis: Measurement is fundamentally distinct from enumeration. Length cannot be determined by counting because (1) there are no minimal length units, and (2) length is not strictly additive at large scales.
METH-014.justification: Given any two lengths, there are intermediate lengths (no minimal units). Even if there were minimal units, determining length by counting would require knowing length is additive - which it isn't (relativity shows length is non-additive).
METH-014.theoretical_significance: Distinguishes quantitative measurement from mere counting, showing measurement requires physical theory

METH-015.title: Relativization to Standards the Essence of Measurement
METH-015.thesis: The essence of measurement is comparison with respect to a standard. All measurement, including 'absolute' measurement, is fundamentally relative comparison to stipulated standards.
METH-015.justification: 'Joe is 6ft tall' seems absolute but actually relativizes Joe's height to a conventional standard (the foot). All measurement assigns magnitudes by comparing to standards.
METH-015.theoretical_significance: Reveals the conventionalist element in all measurement while maintaining measurement's objectivity

METH-016.title: Three Axioms of Measurement Theory
METH-016.thesis: Three axioms are necessary for any viable measurement system: (i) If L1>L2 and L2>L3, then L1>L3 (transitivity). (ii) If L1≠L2, one is greater (trichotomy). (iii) If L1=L2 and L2=L3, then L1=L3 (transitivity of identity). Violation makes measurement meaningless.
METH-016.justification: If these axioms are violated, length-identical objects will be assigned different numbers and length-distinct objects the same number, making assignments meaningless.
METH-016.theoretical_significance: Identifies the minimal formal constraints for coherent quantitative measurement

METH-017.title: Metrical Conventionalism Versus Strict Conventionalism
METH-017.thesis: Conventionalism (laws are convention-based) differs from strict conventionalism (laws are convention-determined). Only the former is correct. That laws are expressed relative to conventional standards doesn't make them entirely conventional.
METH-017.justification: Stipulating the meter doesn't determine how long objects are - they must still be measured. Measurements aren't determined by conventions, only relativized to them. Results are empirical, not conventional.
METH-017.theoretical_significance: Distinguishes moderate from radical conventionalism about physical laws

METH-018.title: Conventionalism Self-Defeating
METH-018.thesis: Conventionalism is self-defeating. If laws hold in virtue of non-conventional relations between conventions and events (as conventionalism requires), then measurement standard choice is constrained by objective facts, undermining conventionalism.
METH-018.justification: Using length-variable eels as standards yields inconsistent measurements (n≠n), while using platinum rods yields consistent results. This shows standards aren't freely choosable but constrained by objective causal structure.
METH-018.theoretical_significance: Refutes conventionalism about physical laws by showing conventions must answer to objective physical facts

METH-022.title: Effective Therapy Requires Purpose-Oriented Reengagement
METH-022.thesis: The way to beat OCD is to have a purpose in life and choose growth over mere freedom from anxiety. Cognitive-behavioral therapy has shallow, short-lived effects absent determination to grow and change in ways that make OCD irrelevant.
METH-022.explanation: Therapeutic methodology that prioritizes existential/volitional commitment over technical interventions.

METH-023.position: The #1 Rule of Writing is that one must immediately write down every thought that occurs

METH-024.position: If one waits to write down a thought, the moment will pass and never be recovered

METH-025.position: The idea that originally comes to mind in writing is merely a foil for a constellation of unconscious ideas

METH-026.position: Following the immediate-writing injunction makes one ipso facto an honest writer

METH-027.position: Complete honesty is the #1 rule of writing (compatible with the immediate-writing rule)

METH-028.position: In business, one must do what comes naturally and not go against one's own grain

METH-029.position: One must work hard, but not work hard fighting one's own nature

METH-030.position: Mind-cure (hypnosis-based precursor of psychoanalysis) has effects similar to religious conversion

METH-031.position: Mind-cure is effective because it relaxes the conscious-unconscious boundary, mending internal divisions

METH-032.position: Psychoanalysis lowers the consciousness-unconsciousness barrier gradually, so emotional changes happen correspondingly slowly

METH-033.position: Recovering from alcoholism tends to involve helping other alcoholics recover

METH-034.position: Wittgenstein's and Quine's paradoxes are motivated by behaviorist psychological theories and, though meant to support such theories, actually presuppose them and show how broken they are

META-001.title: Philosophy as Analysis of Categories
META-001.thesis: Philosophy is the discipline that delineates the structures of the categories in terms of which we think about the world.
META-001.significance: FOUNDATIONAL - defines nature of philosophical inquiry

META-002.title: Philosophy as Meta-Knowledge
META-002.thesis: Philosophical knowledge is metaknowledge—knowledge about knowledge. Philosophy is the analysis of the preconditions of all knowledge.

META-003.title: Philosophy Studies Possibility, Not Actuality
META-003.thesis: Philosophers are interested in what there could be (the possible) more than what there is (the actual).
META-003.consistency: New position consistent with analytical approach

PHIL-004.title: Philosophy as Pathological Symptom Rather Than Pure Inquiry
PHIL-004.thesis: Philosophy, at least in its skeptical and hyper-rationalist forms, is better understood as a pathological symptom analogous to OCD rather than as pure disinterested inquiry into truth.
PHIL-004.explanation: Radical reinterpretation of the nature and motivations of philosophical inquiry, suggesting psychoanalytic rather than purely rational explanations.

PHIL-005.title: Paradigm-Relativism as Psychopathic Magnet
PHIL-005.statement: Concepts like Kuhn's 'paradigm' from The Structure of Scientific Revolutions, along with topics like time travel, quantum theory, relativism, and post-modernism, serve as magnets for truth-concealing psychopaths who swarm over these topics to dismantle life- and thought-critical epistemic instruments without putting anything in their place.
PHIL-005.justification: These topics and conceits attract those who want to undermine the very notion of integrity and objective truth. While some topics (time travel, quantum theory) have inherent legitimacy, they are used illegitimately by psychopaths; others (relativism, postmodernism) have legitimacy only as objects of analysis.
PHIL-005.theoretical_significance: Explains the sociological clustering of certain intellectual positions not as genuine philosophical positions but as indicators of character pathology

PHIL-006.title: Refutation of Intentionalism Through Sellarsian Analysis
PHIL-006.statement: Unless Sellars is completely wrong about the myth of the given, intentionalism must be completely wrong. Since Sellars' anti-foundationalism is now widely accepted and his arguments are compelling, intentionalism should be rejected. The paper merely makes explicit the connection between intentionalism and foundationalism.
PHIL-006.justification: The paper's purpose is to show that intentionalism commits the myth of the given. Given the strength of Sellars' arguments and the wide acceptance of anti-foundationalism, this connection suffices to refute intentionalism without requiring independent argumentation against it.
PHIL-006.theoretical_significance: Illustrates philosophical method of refutation by showing problematic commitments; uses accepted position (anti-foundationalism) to undermine related position (intentionalism)

PHIL-007.title: Translation of Linguistic Work for Philosophical Audiences
PHIL-007.statement: Boguslawski's paper, originally written for linguists, needs translation into the language of philosophy of language for philosophers to understand its relevance to their work. Such translation is not strict - it legitimately involves extending and modifying arguments and contentions for philosophical purposes.
PHIL-007.justification: The paper explicitly presents itself as a 'translation' of Boguslawski's linguistic work, taking liberty to extend and modify arguments for philosophical audiences. Different disciplinary frameworks require reformulation even when core insights are preserved.
PHIL-007.theoretical_significance: Identifies legitimate role of disciplinary translation in philosophy; shows same insights may require different presentations for different scholarly communities

PHIL-008.title: De-psychologizing Kant's Transcendental Arguments
PHIL-008.statement: Despite problems with synthetic a priori, Kant's important claims about causality, personal identity, and rationality are correct and founded on cogent arguments. But to make this apparent, Kant's reasoning must be 'de-psychologized' - statements about psychology reinterpreted as statements about logic. This requires only minor terminological adjustments (replacing 'synthetic a priori' with 'hard analytic').
PHIL-008.justification: Kant's transcendental arguments showing that coherent experience requires certain world-structures are valid when freed from psychologistic framing. The hard-analytic connection between 'there exist beings who raise metaphysical questions' and propositions about world-structure is genuine logical connection, not psychological necessity.
PHIL-008.theoretical_significance: Salvages Kantian insights while rejecting Kantian framework; demonstrates continuity between conceptual analysis and transcendental philosophy

SCI-001.title: Confirmation Requires Principled Generalizations
SCI-001.thesis: Only principled (nomic/causal) generalizations, not accidental generalizations, can be confirmed. When 'All ravens are black' is read as a principled generalization, it has nomic content and is not equivalent to 'All non-black things are non-ravens.'
SCI-001.explanation: This solves Hempel's Raven Paradox. The paradox arises from treating logical equivalence as confirmational equivalence. But (i) 'All ravens are black' read as principled affirms that instances of ravenhood ground/cause instances of blackness. Read thus, (i) is not equivalent with (ii) 'All non-black things are non-ravens' which has no natural nomic reading. Only principled generalizations can be confirmed, and these have causal content that breaks the logical equivalence.
key_points: Logical equivalence does not entail confirmational equivalence
'All x's are y's' when principled has nomic/causal content
Accidental generalizations ('all objects in Smith's pocket expand when heated') cannot be confirmed
Principled generalizations ('all metal expands when heated') can be confirmed

SCI-002.title: AI Systems Test Philosophical Theories Empirically
SCI-002.thesis: Philosophical theories about reasoning, knowledge acquisition, scientific discovery can be empirically tested by examining whether successful AI systems operate according to those theories. AI provides concrete examinable implementations allowing theory adjudication.
SCI-002.methodology: Revolutionary approach—philosophical theories no longer tested only through abstract argumentation but through empirical examination of successful cognitive systems

SCI-003.title: Logic of Discovery is Possible
SCI-003.thesis: Contrary to traditional philosophy of science claiming logic of discovery is impossible, examining AI scientific reasoning reveals identifiable principles guiding successful theory generation. Genuine logic of discovery exists.
SCI-003.principles: Pattern recognition across abstraction levels, integration of statistical/causal reasoning, explanatory coherence maintenance, conservation/innovation balance

SCI-004.title: AI Falsifies Popperian Falsificationism
SCI-004.thesis: AI's success in scientific discovery falsifies Popper's theory that science proceeds primarily through conjecture and refutation. AI systems generate successful theories through pattern matching and inductive generalization, not primarily through bold conjectures and attempts at falsification.
SCI-004.development: This falsifies one of the 20th century's most influential philosophies of science. AI's success through induction contradicts Popper's claim that induction doesn't work and science is only conjectures and refutations.

SCI-005.title: Inductive Discovery Precedes Deductive Testing
SCI-005.thesis: Contra Popper, successful scientific discovery requires inductive pattern recognition to generate plausible hypotheses before deductive testing. AI demonstrates that purely conjectural approaches without inductive guidance are ineffective.
SCI-005.development: This explains why Popper was wrong - discovery requires induction to generate plausible hypotheses. Random conjectures are ineffective. AI shows induction is necessary for science.

SCI-006.title: Reverse Brain Engineering as Scientific Method
SCI-006.thesis: By building AI systems that replicate cognitive functions, we can infer the computational architecture necessary for those functions. This 'reverse engineering' of the brain through AI construction represents a new and powerful methodology in philosophy of science and cognitive science.
SCI-006.development: This proposes a new scientific methodology - reverse engineering through construction. Building AI that works tells us what architecture is necessary for cognition. This is a new way to do cognitive science.

SCI-007.title: AI Falsifies Deductive-Nomological Model of Explanation
SCI-007.thesis: AI's successful explanatory practices falsify the deductive-nomological (covering law) model of explanation. AI generates successful explanations through pattern recognition, analogy, and causal modeling that don't require deduction from universal laws.
SCI-007.development: This falsifies Hempel's famous D-N model of explanation. AI shows that explanation doesn't require subsumption under universal laws - pattern recognition and causal understanding suffice.

SCI-008.title: Causal-Mechanistic Explanation Doesn't Require Universal Laws
SCI-008.thesis: AI demonstrates that causal-mechanistic explanation can be successful without appeal to universal laws. Understanding how something works doesn't require subsuming it under exceptionless generalizations.
SCI-008.development: This shows what replaces the D-N model - causal-mechanistic explanation. Understanding mechanisms suffices for explanation; we don't need universal laws.

SCI-009.title: Explanatory Understanding Through Pattern Recognition
SCI-009.thesis: AI reveals that explanatory understanding can be achieved through recognition of patterns and structural similarities rather than derivation from laws. This suggests explanation is more about grasping relevant relationships than deductive systematization.
SCI-009.development: This provides an alternative account of explanation - pattern recognition. Understanding is grasping relevant patterns and relationships, not deduction from axioms.

SCI-010.title: Laws of Nature Not Confined to Actual Objects
SCI-010.thesis: The scope of natural law is not confined to actual or even possible objects. Many laws hold with respect to classes all of whose members are merely possible or even prohibited by other natural laws.
SCI-010.justification: The law 'an object undergoes no changes if no forces act on it' describes a limiting case prohibited by nature's laws (all objects have forces acting on them). Yet this law is essential for understanding actual cases.
SCI-010.theoretical_significance: Establishes that natural laws govern modal space beyond actuality, including impossible limiting cases

SCI-011.title: Knowledge of Imperceptibles Identical with Conditional Knowledge
SCI-011.thesis: Knowledge of the imperceptible is identical with knowledge of conditional truth. Knowledge of future, past, possible, and imperceptible present states is always conditional knowledge based on laws.
SCI-011.justification: We know future copper will expand when heated by combining the conditional law with specific circumstances. All knowledge beyond direct perception involves conditional reasoning from laws.
