SCI-011.theoretical_significance: Unifies epistemic access to all non-directly-perceived states through conditional knowledge

SCI-012.title: Three Kinds of Imperceptibles
SCI-012.thesis: Physical objects can be imperceptible in three ways: (1) imperceptible due to severed causal processes (objects in other rooms); (2) imperceptible due to size but perceptible with technology (cells, molecules); (3) imperceptible by natural law regardless of technology (photons, subatomic particles).
SCI-012.justification: These three categories exhaust the ways objects can be imperceptible, corresponding to contingent spatial barriers, contingent technological limitations, and necessary law-based limitations.
SCI-012.theoretical_significance: Provides taxonomy of imperceptibility clarifying epistemic access to unobserved entities

SCI-013.title: The Epistemic Function of Natural Law
SCI-013.thesis: Scientists aspire to identify natural laws so they can, when given context-specific information, make true statements about future, past, or possible behavior of contexts. Laws enable conditional prediction and explanation.
SCI-013.justification: Natural laws provide the general principles that, combined with particular facts, allow inference about states beyond direct observation.
SCI-013.theoretical_significance: Identifies the primary epistemic role of scientific laws as enabling conditional inference

SCI-014.title: Science Prioritizes Principles Over Particular Facts
SCI-014.thesis: Any interest science has in a given particular fact is subordinate to its interest in the general principles in terms of which that fact is to be understood. Scientists study particular instances only insofar as they instantiate general laws.
SCI-014.justification: The scientist doesn't care whether studying this versus that penguin except insofar as one instantiates general principles not instantiated by the other.
SCI-014.theoretical_significance: Characterizes the essentially generalizing nature of scientific inquiry

SCI-015.title: Laws May Be Place and Time-Sensitive
SCI-015.thesis: Some natural laws are place- and time-sensitive rather than spatiotemporally invariant. Laws need not hold uniformly across all regions of space-time to be genuine laws.
SCI-015.justification: 'X is human → X is cyanide-intolerant' is a legitimate law even though undefined for most space-time regions (where humans don't exist). Spatiotemporal invariance is not required for law-hood.
SCI-015.theoretical_significance: Liberalizes the concept of natural law to include contextually-restricted generalizations

SCI-016.title: Hume's Regularity Analysis of Causation Is False
SCI-016.thesis: Hume's Regularity Analysis - the view that causation is nothing but constant conjunction, that 'X causes Y' means 'events of type X are regularly followed by events of type Y' - is demonstrably false.
SCI-016.justification: The analysis faces fatal problems: (1) cannot distinguish laws from accidents; (2) requires ad hoc exclusion of coincidental regularities; (3) makes causation empirically undetectable yet claims it's empirically discovered.
SCI-016.theoretical_significance: Comprehensively refutes the empiricist reduction of causation to regularity

SCI-017.title: Hume-Worlds Observationally Different from Non-Humean Worlds
SCI-017.thesis: A Hume-world (where causation equals regularity with no underlying powers) would be observationally different from our world. The concept of a Hume-world cannot support Hume's analysis.
SCI-017.justification: In Hume-worlds, regularities would be brute and inexplicable. Our world exhibits structure, continuity, and proportional relationships inconsistent with pure regularities lacking causal powers.
SCI-017.theoretical_significance: Shows Hume's view is empirically falsifiable and false, not merely a different metaphysical interpretation

SCI-018.title: The Deductive-Nomological Model of Explanation Is False
SCI-018.thesis: The Deductive-Nomological (DN) model - which holds that to explain event E is to derive E from natural laws plus antecedent conditions - is fundamentally mistaken. Explanation requires causal knowledge, not merely law-subsumption.
SCI-018.justification: DN faces fatal circularity: distinguishing laws from accidents requires knowing causal relations; but knowing causal relations already provides explanations, making law-subsumption unnecessary. Laws are derived from, not prior to, causal knowledge.
SCI-018.theoretical_significance: Decisively refutes the dominant 20th-century model of scientific explanation

SCI-019.title: DN Viciously Circular via Counterfactual Support
SCI-019.thesis: The DN model is viciously circular if it requires laws to support counterfactuals (as Hempel proposes). Counterfactuals are cryptocausal statements; knowing them requires knowing causes; but knowing causes already provides explanations.
SCI-019.justification: 'Metal expands when heated' supports counterfactuals only because heating metal causes it to expand. So knowing the law requires knowing causal relations, which already constitutes explanatory knowledge.
SCI-019.theoretical_significance: Exposes the hidden circularity in DN's attempt to distinguish laws from accidents

SCI-020.title: Causal Knowledge as Differential Knowledge
SCI-020.thesis: Causal knowledge is differential knowledge - knowledge of what varies with what. To know causes is to know which changes depend on which other changes and in what proportions.
SCI-020.justification: We know metal expands when heated by observing differential relationships: more heat yields more expansion, less heat yields less expansion. Causal knowledge tracks proportional variations.
SCI-020.theoretical_significance: Provides alternative account of causal knowledge grounded in observation of variations rather than law-subsumption

SCI-021.title: Causation as Proportionality Restoration
SCI-021.thesis: Causation is fundamentally proportionality restoration. Effects are proportional to their causes (threshold effects aside). When a force acts on an object, the resulting change is proportional to the force magnitude.
SCI-021.justification: Physical laws express dependence-relations where effects vary proportionally with causes: size-increase depends on temperature-increase, acceleration depends on force and mass, etc.
SCI-021.theoretical_significance: Identifies proportionality as the mathematical signature of causation

SCI-022.title: Physical Laws as Regularities of Proportion
SCI-022.thesis: Physical laws are regularities of proportion rather than simple universal generalizations. Laws describe how magnitudes vary proportionally with each other rather than stating that all Fs are Gs.
SCI-022.justification: The law 'force equals mass times acceleration' expresses proportional variation. Most fundamental physical laws describe functional dependencies between continuously variable magnitudes.
SCI-022.theoretical_significance: Reconceptualizes natural laws as expressing mathematical proportionality rather than categorical generalization

SCI-023.title: Knowledge-Why Equals High-Resolution Knowledge-What
SCI-023.thesis: To have knowledge-why is to have high-resolution knowledge-what. Explanatory knowledge differs from mere descriptive knowledge in degree of detail and specificity, not in kind.
SCI-023.justification: Knowing Smith is sick because he ate rotten fish provides low-resolution explanation. Knowing the biochemical pathways provides high-resolution explanation. Both are knowledge-what at different levels of detail.
SCI-023.theoretical_significance: Dissolves the sharp distinction between descriptive and explanatory knowledge

SCI-024.title: The Raven Paradox a By-Product of Regularity Analysis
SCI-024.thesis: The Raven Paradox (that non-black non-ravens confirm 'all ravens are black') is an artifact of the Regularity Analysis of causation. Once causation is properly understood, the paradox dissolves.
SCI-024.justification: The paradox arises only if 'all ravens are black' is read extensionally as mere regularity. Read intensionally (causally), it means being a raven causes blackness, which non-black non-ravens don't confirm.
SCI-024.theoretical_significance: Resolves a famous paradox of confirmation theory by appeal to causal structure

SCI-025.title: Determinism Doesn't Entail Complete Predictability
SCI-025.thesis: Determinism (every event has a cause) does not entail complete predictability. Two reasons: (1) interference effects make prediction impossible without infinite precision, and (2) knowledge growth itself cannot be predicted.
SCI-025.justification: Even in deterministic systems, small measurement errors compound through interference. Further, predicting how knowledge will grow would require already having that knowledge (contradiction).
SCI-025.theoretical_significance: Separates metaphysical determinism from epistemological predictability

SCI-026.title: Implementation-Indeterminism Distinguished from Program-Determinism
SCI-026.thesis: Program-determinism (software-level determinism) is compatible with implementation-indeterminism (hardware-level indeterminism). The same program can be implemented by different physical processes.
SCI-026.justification: A computer program deterministically maps inputs to outputs regardless of which specific physical processes implement the computation. Psychology may be program-determined while being implementation-indeterminate.
SCI-026.theoretical_significance: Reconciles determinism with quantum indeterminacy via levels-of-description distinction

SCI-027.title: Truths Not Objects Are Objects of Explanation
SCI-027.thesis: Truths, not objects or states of affairs themselves, are the proper objects of explanation. We explain why propositions are true, not why objects exist (except derivatively).
SCI-027.justification: Explanations provide reasons why something is the case - i.e., why a proposition is true. 'Explain the tree' is elliptical for 'explain why the tree has such-and-such properties' or 'why it exists.'
SCI-027.theoretical_significance: Clarifies the logical structure of explanatory discourse as essentially propositional

SCI-030.title: Relativity Theory Reveals Causal Structure of Spacetime
SCI-030.statement: Recognition that temporal order is causal was forced on us by empirical discoveries, particularly Relativity Theory. If events E and E* are such that no causal signal can pass between them, they have no determinate temporal order. But this recognition that temporal order is causal is itself less like an empirical statement ('all rhenates are chordates') than like a hard analytic truth ('triangles are regions bounded by three coplanar lines').
SCI-030.justification: Relativity shows events outside each other's light cones lack determinate temporal order. This forces recognition of deep connection between causation and temporal structure. Yet this connection, once recognized, seems necessary rather than contingent - it's hard analytic rather than empirical.
SCI-030.theoretical_significance: Shows empirical physics can reveal hard analytic truths about conceptual structure; bridges science and conceptual analysis

SCI-031.title: Complete Description Entails Neighborhood Events
SCI-031.statement: For an arbitrary event E, if D is a complete description of E, then D entails the occurrence of events that, by ordinary standards, are distinct from E. A correct and complete description of an empirical state of affairs permits deduction of events in its neighborhood because spatiotemporal continuity is causal.
SCI-031.justification: Given that any two non-simultaneous states of affairs are causally related and connected by continuous series of events, complete description of one state must contain information determining neighboring states. Discontinuous changes (ex nihilo events) are impossible, so complete description includes continuous transitions.
SCI-031.theoretical_significance: Establishes deductive structure within empirical domain; shows complete empirical knowledge has rational necessity

SCI-032.title: Psychological Versus Physical Explanation Unified
SCI-032.statement: Explanation always consists in showing logical and principled relation between initial and terminal conditions. There is no need to reduce psychology to statistics (Hempel, Mill) or to create artificial division between human and natural sciences (Dilthey). Psychological and physical explanation are fundamentally the same kind - both show why it makes sense that events occurred.
SCI-032.justification: To explain Jim's going to bank is not to subsume behavior under regularity but to show it makes sense given circumstances. Similarly, physical explanation exposes principled relationships, not mere regularities. The word 'explanation' is univocal; differences between psychological and physical explanation reflect subject-matter, not explanatory concept itself.
SCI-032.theoretical_significance: Unifies philosophy of human and natural sciences; refutes positivist and hermeneutic divisions

SCI-033.title: Explanation as Principled Relationship, Not Mere Regularity
SCI-033.statement: Explanation exposes principled relationships, not mere regularities. Regularities express rather than constitute principled relationships. The existence of a regularity (e.g., flipping switch causes light to turn on) is consequence, not substance, of principled relationship among properties. If this is wrong, regularity becomes coincidence of unspeakable proportions.
SCI-033.justification: Given any event, there are infinitely many regularities it instantiates (including 'grue'-style bent predicates). Explanatorily relevant regularities must be distinguished from irrelevant ones. This requires appeal to principled connections, not just statistical patterns. Properties like 'copper' are already inductively committed - circularity in Humean appeal to regularities.
SCI-033.theoretical_significance: Refutes regularity theory of causation and explanation; establishes need for modal/causal primitives in science

SCI-034.position: Logically equivalent statements are not necessarily confirmationally equivalent

SCI-035.position: Confirmation tracks nomic or causal content, not mere logical form

SCI-036.position: 'All metal expands when heated' can be confirmed but not 'all objects in Smith's pocket expand when heated' (only principled generalizations confirmable)

POL-001.title: Market Regulation Necessity Thesis
POL-001.thesis: Financial markets require government regulation to prevent systemic instability. Unregulated financial markets reliably produce crashes that harm the broader economy.
POL-001.source: Analysis of 1929 Crash, 2001 Dot Bomb, 2008 Housing Crisis
POL-001.explanation: The work demonstrates through historical analysis that periods of deregulation (pre-1929, 1978-2004) consistently led to financial crises, while periods of regulation (1933-1978) produced stability and prosperity. This supports the thesis that markets, especially financial markets, do not self-regulate effectively and require governmental oversight.
key_evidence: Pre-1929: Unregulated markets led to stock market bubble and crash
1933-1978: Glass-Steagall regulations prevented major financial crises for 75 years
Post-2008: Dodd-Frank has been effective at preventing bank misconduct
POL-001.philosophical_significance: Challenges libertarian/anarcho-capitalist views that markets are self-correcting; supports mixed economy approaches
POL-001.limitations_noted: Even with regulation, large banking sector can hurt economy without breaking law - some problems cannot be regulated away

POL-002.title: Systemic Risk Justifies Constraint
POL-002.thesis: When private economic activities create systemic risks that endanger the broader economy, government intervention is justified to constrain those activities, even when individual actors are behaving rationally.
POL-002.source: Analysis of bank behaviors leading to 2008 crisis
POL-002.explanation: Banks engaging in risky derivatives trading were individually rational (pursuing profit) but collectively created systemic instability. Glass-Steagall's prohibition on commercial banks doing investment banking prevented banks from using customer deposits to finance risky ventures, thereby reducing systemic risk.
POL-002.key_principle: Individual rationality does not guarantee collective rationality; externalities and systemic effects require collective (governmental) coordination
examples: CDO trading was profitable for individual banks but created housing bubble
Banks borrowing to invest (leverage) maximizes individual returns but creates cascading failures
Interconnected bank failures in 2008 paralyzed entire economy
POL-002.philosophical_framework: Collective action problem requiring Leviathan-style solution

POL-003.title: Separation of Function Principle
POL-003.thesis: Institutions serving essential public functions (like holding customer deposits) should be legally separated from speculative activities to prevent public harm from private risk-taking.
POL-003.source: Analysis of Glass-Steagall Act separating commercial and investment banking
POL-003.explanation: Glass-Steagall recognized that commercial banking (holding deposits, making loans) serves a different public function than investment banking (speculative trading). When these functions are combined, speculative losses can destroy the deposit base, harming innocent customers and the broader economy. The 'firewall' between functions protects public goods from private risks.
POL-003.application: Volcker Rule in Dodd-Frank requires separation via internal firewalls even within single institutions
POL-003.philosophical_principle: Public goods should not be subject to private speculation; essential services require protective constraints

POL-004.title: Transparency as Regulatory Foundation
POL-004.thesis: Market participants must operate with complete transparency to prevent fraud and enable informed decision-making. Opacity in financial markets enables exploitation and systemic instability.
POL-004.source: Discussion of SEC, CFPB, and transparency requirements
POL-004.explanation: The Securities and Exchange Commission requires complete transparency for securities dealers. The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau requires banks to be transparent about loan terms and prohibits hiding behind fine print. These measures prevent predatory behavior and enable informed consent.
examples: CFPB prohibition on hiding terms in fine print
Office of Credit Ratings oversight to ensure credible ratings
POL-004.philosophical_basis: Information asymmetry enables exploitation; markets require transparency to function justly

POL-005.title: Too-Big-To-Fail Paradox
POL-005.thesis: When financial institutions become so large that their failure would catastrophically damage the economy, they must be either regulated more stringently or broken up. Their size creates moral hazard: they can take excessive risks knowing government must rescue them.
POL-005.explanation: Banks deemed 'too big to fail' know they will be bailed out, creating incentive for excessive risk-taking. This moral hazard means profits are privatized while losses are socialized. Dodd-Frank's designation of banks over $250 billion as too-big-to-fail subjects them to enhanced oversight, acknowledging the problem without fully solving it.
POL-005.unresolved_issue: Because banking sector is now so large, it can hurt the economy without breaking the law - problem that cannot easily be regulated away
philosophical_dimensions: Distributive justice - privatized gains, socialized losses
Power concentration - market control by few large actors

POL-013.title: 'Intentions of the Framers' Denotes Idealization Not Empirical Reality
POL-013.thesis: When we speak of 'the intentions of the framers', we are committed to an idealization rather than empirical actuality. The various framers (Adams, Jefferson, Washington) had numerically and qualitatively different minds, so talk of their collective intentions is institutional rather than psychological.
POL-013.explanation: Undermines originalism by showing that its fundamental concept—framers' intentions—doesn't refer to empirical psychological facts but to theoretical constructs.

POL-014.title: Originalism Involves Vicious Circularity
POL-014.thesis: Originalism collapses into circularity (or triviality): Constitutional interpretations are to be evaluated in terms of framers' intentions, but the framers' intentions are to be understood in terms of the historical and social role of Constitutional interpretation.
POL-014.explanation: Core argument against originalism—it cannot provide independent standard for constitutional interpretation because the standard itself presupposes interpretive commitments.

POL-015.title: Framers' Intentions as Theoretical Constructs Presupposing Conceptions of Constitutionality
POL-015.thesis: The expression 'intentions of the framers' denotes an idealization—a theoretical construct with no precise spatiotemporal counterpart. The theories embodied in uses of this expression concern the role the Constitution should have, so originalism is viciously circular or trivial.
POL-015.explanation: Shows that originalism cannot escape theory-dependence—the very concept of framers' intentions is theory-laden.

POL-016.title: Counterfactuals About Framers Presuppose Rather Than Ground Constitutional Interpretations
POL-016.thesis: When legal theorists run counterfactuals about what Jefferson would have said about contemporary issues (like gay marriage), they are not making empirical statements but a priori propositions about what he should have said given his values. This presupposes rather than grounds conceptions of Constitutionality.
POL-016.explanation: Concrete demonstration of circularity problem—shows that seemingly straightforward historical counterfactuals actually presuppose normative commitments.

POL-017.title: Idealized Jefferson Incorporates Normative Commitments About Constitutionality
POL-017.thesis: When we talk about 'what Jefferson would have said', we're talking about what some idealization of Jefferson would have said—a Jefferson purged of cultural limitations and temporal parochialism. This idealization incorporates a certain conception of Constitutionality.
POL-017.explanation: Reveals that historical inquiry into framers' views necessarily involves normative idealization that smuggles in contemporary constitutional commitments.

POL-018.title: 'Jefferson's Values' Denotes Idealization Creating Parallel Circularity
POL-018.thesis: The expression 'Jefferson's values' itself denotes an idealization rather than psychological reality, involving a circularity parallel to that in 'framers' intentions'. We use conceptions of Constitutionality to identify which values are 'his', then use those values to determine Constitutionality.
POL-018.explanation: Shows that the move from 'intentions' to 'values' doesn't escape circularity—both are idealizations that presuppose normative commitments.

POL-019.title: Historical Counterfactuals Replace Empirical Propositions with A Priori Propositions About Values
POL-019.thesis: Once we start dealing with idealizations of framers' psyches rather than their actual psyches, we have replaced empirical propositions about their psychology with a priori propositions about values. Such counterfactuals presuppose conceptions of Constitutionality and thus cannot substantiate them.
POL-019.explanation: Fundamental methodological point: historical inquiry when dealing with idealizations becomes normative inquiry, undermining originalism's claim to ground interpretation in historical facts.

POL-020.title: Originalism Condemns Itself to Vicious Circularity or Innocuous Tautology
POL-020.thesis: The originalist position, when properly understood, collapses into either vicious circularity (using Constitutional conceptions to identify framers' intentions/values, then using those to determine Constitutional meaning) or innocuous tautology (the Constitution means what we think it should mean).
POL-020.explanation: Main thesis of paper—originalism cannot succeed as a theory of constitutional interpretation.

POL-021.title: Originalist Must Identify Values Before Running Counterfactuals, Creating Circle
POL-021.thesis: The originalist is caught in a vicious circle: he must use counterfactuals to identify the values on which his conception of Constitutionality is based, but cannot run those counterfactuals until he has identified those values.
POL-021.explanation: Precise formulation of the circularity problem showing it as a methodological impossibility rather than mere difficulty.

POL-022.title: Free Markets Inherently Generate Irresolvable Wealth Inequalities
POL-022.statement: It is inherent in the free market that it leads to inequalities of wealth and income that cannot be resolved within a free market framework. The free market cannot be expected to diminish the wealth disparities that it itself creates.
POL-022.justification: Market mechanisms systematically advantage those who already have wealth through perception-based value inflation. The market creates inequalities but has no internal mechanism to correct them. Evidence: NYC average income $30K vs top 1% income $3.6M; hedge fund managers earning billions during crisis that impoverished others.
POL-022.chapter: Outline of Economics Paper on Contradictions in Free Market
POL-022.theoretical_significance: Fundamental critique of libertarian faith in market self-correction - shows markets systematically generate unfairness.

POL-023.title: Government Has Responsibility to Correct Market-Generated Inequalities
POL-023.statement: Since the free market cannot diminish the wealth disparities it creates, the government is responsible for diminishing these disparities. Capitalist countries like Sweden enjoy capitalism's benefits while avoiding unjust wealth disparities through progressive taxation.
POL-023.justification: If markets inherently generate irresolvable inequalities, some external mechanism must correct them. Successful capitalist countries like Sweden demonstrate that heavy progressive taxation can preserve market benefits while eliminating unjust disparities. The market's failure to self-correct creates governmental obligation.
POL-023.chapter: Outline of Economics Paper on Contradictions in Free Market
POL-023.theoretical_significance: Justification for progressive taxation and wealth redistribution based on market failure rather than egalitarian ideals.

POL-024.title: War on Drugs Vindicated Libertarian Conception of State's Rightful Role
POL-024.statement: Marijuana legalization constitutes a major victory for the libertarian conception of the state's rightful role. The state should confine itself to preventing clear crimes (assault, rape, theft, fraud) and should refrain from criminalizing acts for purely moral rather than pragmatic reasons.
POL-024.justification: California's marijuana legalization effectively admits the War on Drugs was a complete failure - millions of man-hours wasted on ruinous policies. Drug laws increased drug use, encouraged cartelism, depleted the economy. Right-wing economists (Milton Friedman) were vindicated: anti-drug laws paralyzed free markets and protected drug cartels. 19th century America had no drug laws and lower drug use than after War on Drugs began.
POL-024.chapter: Some Reflections on the Virtues of the Free Market
POL-024.theoretical_significance: Empirical vindication of libertarian political philosophy through natural experiment of drug prohibition and legalization.

POL-025.title: Classical Liberals Vindicated on Drug Policy, Contemporary Liberals Proven Wrong
POL-025.statement: Right-wing economists (free-marketeers like Milton Friedman) were completely vindicated on drug policy: anti-drug laws paralyzed markets, encouraged cartels, depleted economy. Left-wing economists favoring government-created jobs were proven completely wrong.
POL-025.justification: Friedman argued anti-drug laws protected drug cartels - this proved literally true. Free-market economists correctly predicted legalization would improve economy, reduce crime, increase freedom. Left-wing economists favored prohibition-created government jobs despite economic harm. Marijuana legalization empirically vindicated free-market position.
POL-025.chapter: Some Reflections on the Virtues of the Free Market
POL-025.theoretical_significance: Claims empirical vindication of free-market economics over interventionist economics via natural experiment.

POL-026.title: Free Market as Driving Force of Healthy Economy and Culture
POL-026.statement: For classical liberals (Smith, Locke, Hume), ego/individualism is the driving force of a healthy economy, and a healthy economy is the backbone of a healthy culture. Freedom, including economic freedom, is the most natural condition possible.
POL-026.justification: If people with medical/engineering skills can profit from their trade, market pressures naturally make best products available at lowest prices. Ego drives healthy economy. Provided freedoms are constrained just enough for maximal economic freedom for all, there should be no additional restrictions. This was Enlightenment consensus among classical liberals.
POL-026.theoretical_significance: Articulation of classical liberal political economy connecting individual self-interest to collective prosperity.

POL-027.title: Rousseau/Marx View Free Market as Basis of Unnatural Unjust Social Order
POL-027.statement: Opponents of free markets (Rousseau, Marx) regard it as basis of unnatural social order creating horrible inequalities and intolerable deprivations. What classical liberals see as healthy individualism, they see as psychopathic egoism and greed requiring return to pre-capitalist moral purity.
POL-027.justification: Anti-free-marketeers see markets as creating unjust wealth disparities requiring tight government control. Property and economic freedom represent immoral exclusiveness. Solution is return to 'noble savage' who knows nothing of property. Free market individualism is pathological, not healthy.
POL-027.theoretical_significance: Articulation of anti-capitalist critique from Rousseau/Marx tradition as alternative to classical liberalism.

POL-028.title: Plato's Justice Requires Rigid Hierarchical Social Strata Based on Fixed Nature
POL-028.statement: For Plato, justice is identical with people staying in their 'rightful place.' Social position should be determined by one's nature, which cannot relevantly change. Social strata must be rigidly defined with virtually impenetrable barriers between classes.
POL-028.justification: Plato states: 'to do one's own business, in some shape or other, is justice' (433b). People are composed of gold (rulers), silver (auxiliaries), or iron/bronze (workers) - this cannot change. If lower classes acquire property they become hostile masters rather than allies. Justice requires rigid class structure.
POL-028.chapter: Plato's Republic as Pol Potist Bureaucracy
POL-028.theoretical_significance: Critique of Platonic political philosophy as proto-totalitarian rejection of social mobility and individual freedom.

POL-029.title: Plato's Republic Requires Complete Subordination of Private Life to State
POL-029.statement: Plato doesn't acknowledge legitimacy of private life. Entirety of person's life must be subordinate to state interests. Marriages arranged for state benefit, reproduction controlled, no private property, complete collectivization of existence.
POL-029.justification: Plato: marriages must be 'sacred' meaning producing 'most beneficial results' for state (458e). Best must mate with best, inferior with inferior, only best offspring raised (459e). No private households, women common to all men, children held in common, no parent-child knowledge. No private property beyond bare essentials (416d).
POL-029.chapter: Plato's Republic as Pol Potist Bureaucracy
POL-029.theoretical_significance: Demonstrates totalitarian nature of Platonic political vision - complete elimination of private sphere.

POL-030.title: Plato's Justice Completely Depends on State Propaganda and Systematic Lies
POL-030.statement: For Plato, justice depends completely on the state constantly lying to its citizenry, keeping them ignorant, and filling knowledge gaps with carefully constructed propaganda. This is necessary to maintain rigid hierarchical social order.
POL-030.justification: Plato explicitly states: 'no one but rulers must know what is happening, if we are to avoid dissension in our Guardian herd' (459a). Hierarchical arrangement cannot be sustained unless masses kept ignorant and lied to. Nothing more important than unity of state (462b). Deception necessary to maintain 'justice.'
POL-030.chapter: Plato's Republic as Pol Potist Bureaucracy
POL-030.theoretical_significance: Reveals necessary connection between Platonic political philosophy and systematic state deception - proto-Orwellian.

POL-031.title: Plato's Distinction Between Benign and Dangerous Lies Cannot Be Sustained
POL-031.statement: Plato's distinction between benign/beneficial lies and improper/dangerous lies cannot be sustained. Since Plato's conception of justice denies people any freedoms, and such conception is false and evil, any lies told to uphold it are ipso facto evil.
POL-031.justification: According to Plato's justice, nobody entitled to any freedoms - can't listen to music they enjoy, marry people they love, or do much they'd like. Since such restrictive conception is false and evil, there's no principled distinction between good and evil lies in relation to it. All lies supporting unjust system are unjust.
POL-031.chapter: Plato's Republic as Pol Potist Bureaucracy
POL-031.theoretical_significance: Ethical argument that lies cannot be justified by appeal to unjust conception of justice they're meant to preserve.

POL-032.title: Market Economy is Enlightenment Economy Linking Status to Ability Not Birth
POL-032.statement: Since the Enlightenment, one's stature in society has come to depend increasingly on one's own abilities (including intellectual abilities) and decreasingly on social position one was born into. Market economy is Enlightenment/post-Enlightenment economy where ability to acquire/retain property depends largely on intellectual abilities.
POL-032.justification: Market economy connects with Enlightenment values. As markets became freer in mid-1700s, average citizen increasingly able and obligated to stake own claim in marketplace. This required self-reliance/autonomy (Kant's term). In truly free market nothing permanent, individuals can't rely on institutions but only on own ability, so people must decide for themselves how lives will be.
POL-032.theoretical_significance: Links market economics to Enlightenment philosophical values of autonomy and merit-based social organization.

POL-033.title: Kant's Enlightenment Autonomy Has Operational Meaning Only in Market Economy
POL-033.statement: Kant's exhortation to 'have the courage to use your own understanding' has operational meaning only in market economy. In non-market economy it's meaningless - indentured servant who thinks for himself gains nothing practical. But in market economy one has nothing to rely on but own judgment.
POL-033.justification: In non-market economy exhorting servant to 'think for himself' is without operational meaning - even if he does, it won't do him practical good. But in market economy that exhortation is on point since one ultimately has nothing to rely on other than own judgment. This is why general education replaced apprenticeships for workforce induction.
POL-033.theoretical_significance: Connects Kantian moral philosophy of autonomy to economic structure - autonomy requires market conditions.

POL-034.title: Legal Freedom Compatible with Complete Substantive Enslavement
POL-034.statement: The freedoms people have in market economy (to own and exchange goods and services) inevitably lead to complete mutual enslavement under pretexts of 'universal legal protection of rights' and 'economic freedom.' Legal freedom coexists with substantive slavery.
POL-034.justification: Market economy turns people into commodities/spectacles (pornography best example). Woman who 'freely' becomes stripper started with legal freedoms but had to dispose of them to eat/pay rent. She 'freely' chose most rational option given available choices, yet all this 'freedom' has made her a slave. Her situation not unambiguously different from actual slavery, though every move is 'free.'
POL-034.chapter: Legal vs. Substantive Freedom and the Paradox of the Free Market
POL-034.theoretical_significance: Radical critique distinguishing legal/formal freedom from substantive freedom - market 'freedom' can constitute actual slavery.

POL-035.title: Free Market Turns People Into Commodities and Mere Spectacles
POL-035.statement: Market-based society, as opposed to culture-based society, inevitably turns people into objects or 'mere spectacles' (Debord's term). Pornography is paradigm case: human being literally turned into commodity that exists only to be consumed by being looked at.
POL-035.justification: In market economy people have value only insofar as others willing to give them money. Woman becomes pornographic actress because she needs money and in market economy her options are soul-destroying menial work for paltry income or making real money by literally turning herself into spectacle. Market reduces persons to commodities.
POL-035.chapter: Legal vs. Substantive Freedom and the Paradox of the Free Market
POL-035.theoretical_significance: Fundamental critique of commodification of persons in market economies using sex work as clearest example.

ECON-001.title: Financial Stability Requires Counter-Cyclical Policy
ECON-001.thesis: Markets left to themselves exhibit boom-bust cycles. Preventing severe busts requires counter-cyclical intervention: tightening during booms, loosening during busts. The Fed's pro-cyclical tightening after 1929 crash turned it into Depression.
ECON-001.source: Analysis of Fed response to 1929 crash vs. 2008 crisis
ECON-001.explanation: After 1929, the Fed tightened monetary policy, viewing bank failures as 'healthy correction,' which deepened the crisis into Depression. After 2008, government loosened policy (EESA, ESA, near-zero interest rates), preventing Depression. This demonstrates markets don't self-correct - downturns can become self-reinforcing without intervention.
ECON-001.key_insight: Market 'corrections' can overshoot dramatically without counter-cyclical policy

ECON-002.title: Credit as Essential Economic Function
ECON-002.thesis: Economies depend on credit as much as on wealth. When credit dries up, economic activity contracts even if wealth remains. Banking crises are particularly dangerous because they destroy credit availability.
ECON-002.source: Analysis of how 2008 banking crisis decapitalized banks and restricted credit
ECON-002.explanation: The housing crisis decreased wealth; the banking crisis decreased credit. The second was worse because businesses cannot operate without ability to borrow. A credit crunch prevents wealth regeneration even after losses.
ECON-002.implication: Protecting banking system stability is crucial for economic functioning, not just for banks themselves

ECON-003.title: Exchange Value is Perception-Based, Use Value is Reality-Based
ECON-003.statement: Exchange value is fundamentally perception-based rather than reality-based, while use value is reality-based. For this reason, there is no limit to how much exchange value and use value can diverge from one another.
ECON-003.justification: Exchange value depends on perceived utility, not actual utility. A college degree may have zero or negative use-value but enormous exchange-value based on perception. Objects can be assigned conventional value independent of utility (Justin Bieber's hair). This divergence is unlimited because perceptions can diverge arbitrarily from reality.
ECON-003.theoretical_significance: Fundamental distinction undermining classical economic theory's assumption that market prices reflect actual value. Shows systematic way markets can misallocate resources.

ECON-004.title: Wealth Divergence Between Exchange and Use Value Exacerbates Inequality
ECON-004.statement: The divergence between exchange value and use value tends to inflate the value of wealthy people's assets and deflate the value of poor people's assets, thereby exacerbating pre-existing inequalities.
ECON-004.justification: When commodities are associated with wealth (Gucci handbags), their exchange value rises relative to use value. When associated with poverty (K-mart clothes), exchange value falls relative to use value. The wealthy can inflate asset values through fiat simply by association. This widens the chasm between rich and poor independent of actual utility.
ECON-004.theoretical_significance: Shows how market mechanisms systematically advantage the wealthy independent of productivity or merit - fundamental critique of market fairness.

ECON-005.title: 2008 Crisis Exemplifies Dual Divergence of Exchange from Use Value
ECON-005.statement: The 2008 financial crisis was caused by two distinct divergences between exchange value and use value: first, worthless housing was made to seem valuable; second, worthless housing-backed securities created additional false perception-based capital.
ECON-005.justification: The crisis wasn't just preceded by over-valuation - that's what caused it. Housing exchange value was inflated relative to use value through perception manipulation. Then securities backed by this worthless housing created a second layer of purely perception-based capital. Fund managers profited enormously by detecting and exploiting these divergences.
ECON-005.theoretical_significance: Concrete demonstration of theoretical point about exchange/use value divergence with massive real-world consequences.

ECON-006.title: Anti-Drug Laws Create Zero-Sum Bureaucracies That Are Net Economic Parasites
ECON-006.statement: The state apparatus relating to drug prohibition - educators, probation officers, prison personnel - are zero-sum bureaucracies: useless parasites contributing nothing while being paid at taxpayer expense, actually harming those they supposedly help.
ECON-006.justification: Once marijuana is legal, those who enforced prohibition are revealed as bureaucrats who wasted resources on ruinous policies. They didn't reduce drug use (which increased), they didn't improve society, they created massive costs. They're parasites: paid to harm people at those people's expense.
ECON-006.chapter: Some Reflections on the Virtues of the Free Market
ECON-006.theoretical_significance: Radical critique of government bureaucracy using drug war as paradigm case of how state programs can be net harmful.

ECON-007.title: Drug Prohibition is Economic Argument for Universal Drug Legalization
ECON-007.statement: For strictly economic reasons (not civil liberty reasons), it is necessary to make all drugs legal unconditionally. 90% of inmates are drug offenders; imprisoning them is expensive and prevents economic contribution; drug offenders are non-violent and don't abridge others' freedoms.
ECON-007.justification: Economic costs are enormous: imprisoning 90% of inmates (drug offenders) requires paying guards, physicians, contractors while those imprisoned can't contribute to economy. These are non-violent offenders not guilty of theft, fraud, or abridging others' freedoms. Pure economic calculation demands legalization independent of liberty arguments.
ECON-007.theoretical_significance: Attempt to provide consequentialist economic argument for drug legalization separate from deontological liberty arguments.

ECON-008.title: Knowledge-Capital More Important Than Property-Capital in Market Economies
ECON-008.statement: In today's market economy, knowledge is more important than property. Person with unlimited knowledge but no property can acquire unlimited property. Person with property but no knowledge can only hold position, not grow it. Knowledge alone enables satisfying market demands.
ECON-008.justification: Person A with unlimited knowledge can acquire and grow property limitlessly. Person B with property but no intelligence can only hold onto existing property, not grow it (setting aside blind luck). In market economy, anyone who can satisfy market demands can add to holdings - knowledge and knowledge alone enables this.
ECON-008.theoretical_significance: Shift from property-based to knowledge-based conception of capital with implications for understanding inequality and opportunity.

ECON-009.title: Market Economies Incentivize Education, Command Economies Do Not
ECON-009.statement: In feudal or command economies, property seldom passes between persons - such economies are static. Participants focus on property retention not acquisition, so investing in education doesn't pay since no guarantee of marketing it. In market economies there is such guarantee since one can always trade knowledge for property.
ECON-009.justification: Feudal/command economies have little social mobility - no way to improve one's lot through education since can't market skills. But market economy provides guarantee one can trade knowledge for property - can always find way to convert skill into wealth. This creates incentive for education absent in static economies.
ECON-009.theoretical_significance: Economic argument for how market structures create different incentives for human capital investment.

ECON-010.title: Market Freedom Paradox: Freedom Used Rationally Produces Slavery
ECON-010.statement: There is a paradox of market freedom: legal freedoms, when disposed of in most rational manner given available options, produce complete enslavement. Rationality and freedom turn against themselves to enslave their possessor.
ECON-010.justification: Person starts with legal freedoms. To survive (eat, pay rent), must dispose of freedoms in manner that given options is most 'rational' and that person 'freely' chooses. Yet all this 'freedom' and 'rationality' has turned against itself making possessor into slave. Legal freedom coexists with substantive slavery when market constrains 'free' choices to all-enslaving options.
ECON-010.chapter: Legal vs. Substantive Freedom and the Paradox of the Free Market
ECON-010.theoretical_significance: Paradox revealing deep tension in liberal political economy between formal and substantive conceptions of freedom.

ECON-011.title: Fund Managers Profit by Exploiting Exchange-Use Value Divergences
ECON-011.statement: Fund managers make money by dumping over-valued assets and buying under-valued assets. Their income depends entirely on detecting discrepancies between use-value and exchange-value. Their activities may themselves enlarge those discrepancies.
ECON-011.justification: Fund managers earned hundreds of millions to billions annually during 2008 crisis by exploiting use-exchange value gaps. If Warren Buffett dumps stock, he deflates exchange value even if use value unchanged; if he buys, he inflates exchange value even if use value unchanged. They profit from and amplify divergence.
ECON-011.theoretical_significance: Shows how financial markets create incentives to maintain and exploit use-exchange value divergences rather than correct them.

ETHICS-001.title: Ability-Character Complementarity
ETHICS-001.thesis: Human abilities differ little by nature; it is habits and character (diligence, persistence) that separate people. Genius is made through dilligence, not born.
ETHICS-001.source: Multiple dialogues on ability, talent, and achievement
ETHICS-001.explanation: The Master teaches: 'Men's natures differ little. It is their habits that separate them.' And: 'Without dilligence, there is raw talent, but no ability, and certainly no genius.' This challenges nativist views about talent and emphasizes the role of character and sustained effort.
key_quotes: 'Ability is only half the battle. Fulfillment of one's expectations depends on dilligence'
'The mechanic who would perfect his craft must first sharpen his tools'
philosophical_implications: Nurture over nature in human development
Virtue of diligence as essential to achievement
Character development as foundation for success

ETHICS-002.title: Process Over Outcomes in Evaluation
ETHICS-002.thesis: What matters is success relative to failure, not the absence of failure. 'Our greatest glory lies not in never falling but in getting up every time we do.' Successful people stumble many times; their successes, not their failures, define them.
ETHICS-002.source: Dialogues on failure, success, and perseverance
ETHICS-002.explanation: The Master teaches that all successful people fail many times on their way to success. The key is persistence and the rate of success relative to failure, not avoiding failure entirely.
ETHICS-002.key_teaching: 'It doesn't matter how often you fail. It matters how often you succeed.'
ETHICS-002.philosophical_principle: Resilience and persistence as virtues; failure as learning opportunity rather than final judgment

ETHICS-003.title: Pace Irrelevance in Progress
ETHICS-003.thesis: The rate of progress doesn't matter; what matters is continuous forward motion. 'It does not matter how slowly you go, just as long as you do not stop.'
ETHICS-003.explanation: Echoing the tortoise-and-hare fable, the Master emphasizes that consistent effort matters more than speed. This counsels patience and persistence over trying to match faster competitors.

ETHICS-004.title: Internal vs. External Worth
ETHICS-004.thesis: One should not worry that nobody knows who you are; worry that you are not worth knowing. The problem is not lack of recognition but lack of actual merit.
ETHICS-004.explanation: This prioritizes actual virtue and capability over reputation. The Master redirects concern from external recognition to internal development, placing responsibility on the individual to become worthy rather than demanding recognition.
ETHICS-004.philosophical_tradition: Stoic focus on internal goods; Confucian self-cultivation

ETHICS-005.title: Universal Teacherhood Principle
ETHICS-005.thesis: Everyone can be a teacher: from superiors one learns what to do; from inferiors one learns what not to do. 'If I am with two men, one my inferior, the other my superior, each is my teacher.'
ETHICS-005.source: Dialogue on learning from wise men vs. fools
ETHICS-005.explanation: This transforms the problem that 'for every wise man there are a thousand fools.' Fools become 'inverted wise men' - they demonstrate what not to do. This makes everyone a potential teacher and every situation a learning opportunity.
ETHICS-005.epistemic_principle: Negative exemplars are as instructive as positive ones; mistakes teach as much as successes

ETHICS-006.title: Commitment Completeness Principle
ETHICS-006.thesis: Whatever you do, do it with your whole heart. Full commitment to chosen path is more important than which path is chosen.
ETHICS-006.source: Dialogue on choosing between career paths
ETHICS-006.explanation: When the Student faces a choice between mutually exclusive paths, the Master doesn't advise which to choose but emphasizes total commitment to whatever is chosen. This suggests wholehearted engagement matters more than the specific object of that engagement.
ETHICS-006.philosophical_principle: Authenticity and full engagement as virtues; half-hearted efforts fail regardless of path

ETHICS-007.title: Anger's Misguiding Influence
ETHICS-007.thesis: Under anger's influence, conduct is misguided. One should take a time-out and revisit situations from a calmer vantage. Before acting in anger, think of the consequences.
ETHICS-007.explanation: The Master counsels against acting on anger, noting that 'to be wronged is trivial unless you insist on perpetuating that wrong by continuing to dwell on it.' This emphasizes emotional regulation and consequentialist thinking about anger-driven actions.
ETHICS-007.key_teaching: Anger impairs judgment; temporal distance and consequence-consideration necessary before action
ETHICS-007.virtue_emphasized: Self-control, emotional regulation, wisdom about consequences

ETH-009.title: Pathological Concern with Ethics Derives from Crypto-Criminal Orientation
ETH-009.thesis: Both obsessive-compulsives and philosophers are pathologically concerned with ethics because they are crypto-criminals whose fundamental orientation is anti-social, but who have draconian superegos and thus suppress their criminal side.
ETH-009.explanation: Provides psychological explanation of excessive ethical concern as reaction formation against anti-social impulses.

ETH-010.title: Deontological Ethics Precludes Coercive Wealth Redistribution
ETH-010.statement: According to deontological ethics (Kant, Ross), wealth cannot legitimately be redistributed through coercion, even if equal distribution would be desirable. The means (coercing people, thwarting autonomy) cannot be justified by the ends (wealth equality).
ETH-010.justification: Deontologists hold that ends don't justify means. Acting morally is about respecting people and allowing autonomous exercise of freedom, not righting social wrongs through coercion. Appreciable wealth requires free enterprise, which requires autonomous agents. Preventing autonomous exercise to achieve wealth equality would be doubly wrong: coercion + autonomy-thwarting. No way to achieve or maintain equal distribution without such coercion.
ETH-010.theoretical_significance: Deontological argument against wealth redistribution independent of consequentialist concerns about economic efficiency.

ETH-011.title: Kant and Ross Would Not Regard Wealth Equality as Particularly Desirable
ETH-011.statement: Even if there were morally innocuous way of achieving/maintaining wealth equality, neither Kant nor Ross would regard it as particularly desirable state of affairs. They would see it as desirable only to extent necessary for people to treat each other with respect - not clear that wealth equality particularly conducive to that end.
ETH-011.justification: Deontologists care about respect and autonomy, not outcomes like wealth equality. Equal wealth desirable only insofar as needed for mutual respect. Since unclear whether wealth equality particularly conducive to respectful treatment (might even hinder it by requiring coercive enforcement), deontologists wouldn't necessarily value it highly.
ETH-011.theoretical_significance: Shows deontological ethics doesn't entail egalitarian economic outcomes - process matters more than distribution.

ETH-012.title: Lies Cannot Be Justified by Unjust Ends They Serve
ETH-012.statement: If a conception of justice is fundamentally unjust (denying basic freedoms), then lies told to maintain that conception cannot be distinguished into good and bad lies. All lies serving unjust ends are thereby unjust regardless of intentions.
ETH-012.justification: The distinction between beneficial and harmful lies depends on justice of system they serve. If system fundamentally denies human freedom (like Plato's Republic), then no lies supporting it can be 'beneficial' - they're all harmful by virtue of supporting unjust system. Can't have benign lies serving malign purposes.
ETH-012.chapter: Plato's Republic as Pol Potist Bureaucracy
ETH-012.theoretical_significance: Ethical principle that means cannot be separated from ends - lies inherit injustice of unjust systems they support.

ETH-013.title: Psychopathic Discourse as Career-Based Integrity Undermining
ETH-013.statement: When people engage in hand-waving about deconstructionism, narratives, and critiques, they are revealed as individuals who themselves have no integrity and whose careers constitute attempts to undermine the very notion of integrity. One should promptly disengage from such people.
ETH-013.justification: Such discourse is not merely confused but actively fraudulent and destructive. Those who engage in it are 'feather-head twigs' wasting others' time and systematically attacking the foundations of meaningful communication and thought.
ETH-013.theoretical_significance: Provides ethical guidance on engaging with certain forms of academic discourse; identifies intellectual fraud as warranting social disengagement

ETH-014.title: Psychopathy as Categorical Moral Incapacity
ETH-014.statement: Psychopaths lack conscience and are fundamentally incapable of genuine moral engagement. Their callous disregard for others, manipulativeness, and deceitfulness constitute not mere moral failings but categorical incapacity for the moral domain. They cannot form the kinds of attachments and relationships that ground normal moral agency.
ETH-014.justification: The lack of conscience in psychopathy is not a degree of moral failing but a kind-difference. Where normal persons can have relationships that ground moral obligations, psychopaths can only use others instrumentally, precluding the relational foundation of morality.
ETH-014.theoretical_significance: Identifies psychopathy as limiting case for moral philosophy where capacity for moral agency itself is absent; challenges universalist ethics that presume all agents have moral capacity

VIRTUE-001.title: Superior Person's Vigilant Stability
VIRTUE-001.thesis: The superior person maintains stable, centered attitude while being appropriately responsive to changing circumstances. 'When resting in safety, does not forget danger may come. When secure, does not overlook possibility of ruin. When orderly, knows disorder may come. Therefore, when disaster strikes, is ready.'
VIRTUE-001.explanation: This articulates an ideal of psychological and practical preparedness that avoids both naive optimism and paranoid anxiety. The superior person is never caught off-guard because they maintain awareness of possible disasters while enjoying security.
VIRTUE-001.key_virtue: Prudent vigilance without anxiety; preparedness without paranoia
VIRTUE-001.philosophical_tradition: Stoic premeditatio malorum; Confucian junzi (superior person)

VIRTUE-002.title: Judicious Speech as Virtue
VIRTUE-002.thesis: The superior person is careful about what they say and how they say it; they do not speak loosely. Carefulness in speech reflects carefulness in thought and respect for words' consequences.
VIRTUE-002.explanation: The Student observes the Master is 'very judicious about what you say and how you say it. Not exactly reserved. But very careful.' The Master affirms this is characteristic of the superior person.

VIRTUE-003.title: Practice-Preaching Unity
VIRTUE-003.thesis: The superior person practices what they preach and either reconciles themselves to their situation or changes it. They are never idle.
VIRTUE-003.explanation: This articulates a principle of integrity (unity of word and deed) combined with active problem-solving. The superior person doesn't complain about situations they could change but don't, nor do they passively accept what they should change.
VIRTUE-003.key_principle: Either change situation or accept it; no middle ground of complaint without action
VIRTUE-003.philosophical_tradition: Stoic dichotomy of control; Confucian integrity

VIRTUE-004.title: Moral Courage as Essential Virtue
VIRTUE-004.thesis: To know what you must do and still not do it shows lack of moral courage, which is the worst sin. Excellence requires moral courage, not merely will power.
VIRTUE-004.source: Dialogue on will power and courage
VIRTUE-004.explanation: The Student asks about having will power to do the right thing. The Master corrects: 'It is not a question of will power. It is a question of courage. Moral courage.' This makes moral courage central to ethics - the ability to act on what one knows is right.
VIRTUE-004.key_distinction: Will power vs. moral courage - knowing the right and having courage to act on it
VIRTUE-004.philosophical_import: Knowing good insufficient; must have courage to act

VIRTUE-005.title: Earnest Striving Constitutes Achievement
VIRTUE-005.thesis: If you earnestly try to be a superior person, you are, for that very reason, on your way to being such a person. The sincere attempt itself constitutes progress toward the goal.
VIRTUE-005.explanation: This teaching removes the paradox of 'how can I become what I'm not?' The answer: earnest striving toward the ideal itself makes one more like the ideal. There's no gap between trying and succeeding - trying is succeeding.
VIRTUE-005.philosophical_principle: Process and goal united in virtue development; becoming through striving

PSYCH-001.title: Problem Portability
PSYCH-001.thesis: Wherever you go, there you are. Your problems tend to follow you. External change without internal change doesn't solve problems.
PSYCH-001.explanation: When Student wants to transfer schools and move cities, the Master teaches that problems are often internal and will follow. This counsels internal change over mere external change.
PSYCH-001.practical_wisdom: Fix yourself before trying to fix circumstances; location changes don't solve character issues

PSYCH-002.title: Universal Beauty Under Blindness
PSYCH-002.thesis: Everything is beautiful, but most people are blind to most of the beauty. The ugliness perceived in the world reflects perceptual limitations rather than absence of beauty.
PSYCH-002.source: Dialogue on ugliness in the world
PSYCH-002.explanation: The Master responds to complaint about 'so much ugliness' by asserting universal beauty with selective perception. This is either metaphysical (beauty is omnipresent) or epistemic (proper perception reveals beauty everywhere).
PSYCH-002.philosophical_dimension: Aesthetic realism or perceptual constructivism about beauty

PSYCH-003.title: Ability-Demand Asymmetry
PSYCH-003.thesis: Ability will never catch up with the demand for it. There is always more need for ability than supply of it.
PSYCH-003.source: Dialogue on abilities being economically useful
PSYCH-003.explanation: This provides reassurance that developed abilities will find application. Market for competence exceeds supply, suggesting ability development is always worthwhile investment.
PSYCH-003.practical_implication: Optimism about value of skill development

PSY-007.title: Philosophers and Obsessive-Compulsives Share Compulsive Doubt
PSY-007.thesis: Philosophers and obsessive-compulsives are both compulsive doubters who doubt the obvious, rationalizing this as rigor while actually expressing impotence and fear of engaging the world.
PSY-007.explanation: Reveals psychological roots of philosophical skepticism and connects philosophical methodology to clinical psychopathology.

PSY-008.title: Philosophers and OCD Sufferers Manipulate Symbolic Proxies Instead of Reality
PSY-008.thesis: Both philosophers and obsessive-compulsives deal with linguistic and symbolic proxies of reality rather than engaging the world directly, seeking dominance in the sphere of thought where they have power.
PSY-008.explanation: Explains the retreat into abstraction and symbolic manipulation as a defensive maneuver seeking control.

PSY-009.title: Preoccupation with Logical Niceties Derives from Impotence
PSY-009.thesis: Both philosophers and obsessive-compulsives are unduly preoccupied with logical niceties and fine points of argumentation as a derivative of their sense of impotence and lack of material to work on.
PSY-009.explanation: Reveals methodological obsessions as symptoms of psychological withdrawal rather than genuine epistemological concerns.

PSY-010.title: Mental Illness is Contextual; Physical Illness is Not
PSY-010.thesis: Mental illnesses are contextual in nature—being an asset in some contexts and a liability in others—while physical illnesses like asthma, lupus, or cancer are simply liabilities in all contexts.
PSY-010.explanation: Fundamental distinction between mental and physical illness that challenges medical model of mental illness.

PSY-011.title: Mental Illness Serves Defensive Function
PSY-011.thesis: Mental illnesses serve a defensive/protective function, insulating the subject in a psychological 'safe-space' from toxic and threatening environments, even though they are dysfunctional in some respects.
PSY-011.explanation: Reframes mental illness as adaptive (though costly) response to environmental threats rather than pure pathology.

PSY-012.title: Mental Illness Involves Misdeployed Strengths
PSY-012.thesis: Some mental illnesses involve misdeployed strengths of intellect and character—OCD involves misdeployed intelligence and focus; schizophrenia involves misdeployed creativity and emotional sensitivity.
PSY-012.explanation: Suggests mental illness involves qualitative differences in psychological organization rather than simple deficits.

PSY-013.title: Psychiatric Munchausen's by Proxy as Covert Child Abuse
PSY-013.thesis: Parents (usually mothers) get psychiatrists to falsely diagnose their children with autism, Asperger's, ADHD to gain attention, resulting in covert child murder through damaging over-attention from educational and psychiatric bureaucrats.
PSY-013.explanation: Critique of psychiatric diagnosis as potentially iatrogenic and serving parental/professional needs rather than child welfare.

PSY-014.title: OCD is Ultimately Voluntary
PSY-014.thesis: OCD is ultimately a voluntary condition and an affliction of the will. If one chooses to leave the defensive bubble and re-engage the world, OCD becomes irrelevant or assumes benign/productive forms.
PSY-014.explanation: Radical voluntarist position on mental illness that challenges medical model and emphasizes agency.

PSY-015.title: OCD Prognosis Depends on Volitional Choice
PSY-015.thesis: The prognosis for OCD is 100% positive if seen as ultimately voluntary, but negative if seen as garden-variety pathology outside the scope of will. OCD is eliminated or made adaptive by exercising will in growth-oriented ways.
PSY-015.explanation: Links therapeutic outcomes to metaphysical commitments about voluntariness and agency.

PSY-016.title: Auto-hypnosis is Essential for Action
PSY-016.thesis: Auto-hypnosis (giving oneself commands whose efficacy doesn't depend on conscious judgment) is essential for action. Without it, one would be the ultimate bureaucrat who never does anything requiring sustained enthusiasm.
PSY-016.explanation: Positive account of non-rational psychological processes as necessary for agency rather than obstacles to it.

PSY-017.title: Psychopathy as Complete Lack of Integrity
PSY-017.statement: Psychopathy is fundamentally defined as a complete lack of integrity, rather than by specific behavioral symptoms or clinical criteria.
PSY-017.justification: This is the essential defining characteristic from which all forms of psychopathy derive. Whether early-onset, bureaucratic, or academic, all psychopaths share this core feature of total integrity deficit.
PSY-017.theoretical_significance: Provides unified definition of psychopathy across disparate manifestations, grounding the concept in moral/character terms rather than purely behavioral or neurological ones

PSY-018.title: Early-Onset Psychopathy: Failure to Develop Character Architecture
PSY-018.statement: Early-onset psychopaths never develop the character-architecture of normal persons; any appearance of such architecture is pure fabrication. These individuals become con-artists, grifters, drifters, and cult-leaders.
PSY-018.justification: When lack of integrity sets in very early in life, the person never constructs genuine characterological properties, only simulated ones for manipulative purposes.
PSY-018.theoretical_significance: Distinguishes developmental trajectory of early versus late-onset psychopathy; explains why early-onset psychopaths are more obviously 'phony' and plastic

PSY-019.title: Bureaucratic Psychopathy: Late-Onset Institutional Submission
PSY-019.statement: A vastly more common form of psychopathy is 'bureaucratic psychopathy' (bureaupath), in which individuals forfeit their integrity late in life to fit into bureaucratic institutions or pseudo-legitimate professional areas like academia or law. These individuals retain the formal properties of normal character but have become hollow husks in whom 'the magic is gone and the spark is gone.'
PSY-019.justification: This form of psychopathizing occurs through institutional submission and political accommodation. Unlike early-onset psychopaths, bureaupaths developed normal character architecture before psychopathizing, so they retain its formal structure even after integrity is lost.
PSY-019.theoretical_significance: Identifies institutional contexts as psychopathy-producing; explains why late-onset institutional psychopaths seem more 'normal' than con-artist types despite being equally psychopathic

PSY-020.title: Academic Humanities Psychopathy: Truth-Concealing Through Pseudo-Cognitive Categories
PSY-020.statement: A third type of late-onset psychopathy, prevalent in humanities academia, involves projecting one's failure to understand onto the object of non-understanding by 'sliming it up' with spongiform pseudo-cognitive categories like 'narrative,' 'critique,' and 'literature' rather than admitting non-comprehension.
PSY-020.justification: This is psychopathic because it is driven by narcissism, hate, and infinite disregard for truth. People employing such categories don't understand the material but want to seem authoritative, so they conceal their ignorance by degrading the object itself into vague meta-categories.
PSY-020.theoretical_significance: Identifies specific linguistic markers of intellectual psychopathy; explains prevalence of relativist discourse in humanities as character pathology rather than intellectual position

PSY-021.title: Basic Tenet of Attachment Theory
PSY-021.statement: A person's emotional attachments influence the way in which he deals with problematic situations, and the way in which he deals with problematic situations influences his relations to others. Attachment Theory is a cluster of theories based on this fundamental tenet.
PSY-021.justification: This is empirically validated common knowledge, embodied in parental instincts. Parents, especially mothers, are naturally inclined to bond with children, particularly when young and vulnerable, indicating innate recognition of attachment's importance for psychological health.
PSY-021.theoretical_significance: Establishes foundational principle connecting early-life relationships to adult psychological functioning; grounds all subsequent attachment theory research

PSY-022.title: Freud's Account of Character Architecture
PSY-022.statement: According to Freud, a psychologically healthy adult is someone whose parents loved him but did not spoil him. The mother's job is to provide love (leading to self-love), and the father's job is to provide discipline (leading to self-discipline). Adult success depends on having a healthy combination of self-love and self-discipline.
PSY-022.justification: Freud explicitly stated that a person's character-architecture as an adult is largely a consequence of early-life relations to parents and worked out in detail how these attachments determine psychological profile. Maternal love provides self-confidence for success; paternal discipline tempers this with necessary self-control.
PSY-022.theoretical_significance: Provides early psychoanalytic foundation for attachment theory; identifies differential parental roles in character development

PSY-023.title: Bowlby's Attachment Behavioral System
PSY-023.statement: An 'attachment behavioral system' (ABS) refers to the behaviors and attitudes that determine how a person forms relationships and deals with abandonment. A person's ABS is largely determined by the nature of early-life relationships with caregivers. To become a healthy adult, a child needs at least one stable attachment with a caregiver.
PSY-023.justification: Bowlby observed that children who reacted most violently to caregiver separation were first to receive substitute caregivers and most likely to survive. He hypothesized these extreme behaviors were survival mechanisms reinforced by natural selection, constituting an evolved behavioral system.
PSY-023.theoretical_significance: Introduces evolutionary-biological foundation for attachment; identifies ABS as key psychological structure mediating relationship formation across lifespan

PSY-024.title: Four Basic Infant Attachment Patterns
PSY-024.statement: There are four basic attachment patterns in infants: (1) Secure - happy, confident, boldly exploratory with nurturing caregivers; (2) Anxious-ambivalent - cautious, worried about caregiver departure, with withdrawn/unreliable caregivers; (3) Anxious-avoidant - not distressed by departure, avoid caregiver on return, focus on physical environment, have abusive caregivers; (4) Disorganized - respond with fear to returning caregivers, have extremely abusive or highly unreliable caregivers.
PSY-024.justification: Research based on Bowlby's work empirically established these four distinct patterns characterized by different behavioral responses to caregiver presence/absence and different caregiver qualities.
PSY-024.theoretical_significance: Provides empirical taxonomy of attachment styles; establishes correlation between caregiver behavior and infant attachment pattern

PSY-025.title: Persistence of Attachment Patterns Through Development
PSY-025.statement: The four attachment patterns (secure, anxious-ambivalent, anxious-avoidant, disorganized) persist from infancy through childhood into adulthood, though with developmentally appropriate manifestations. There is good evidence that a child's attachment pattern tends to be identical with the one he had as an infant, though categorical identity remains an open question. Some evidence suggests adults can have different attachment patterns from earlier life.
PSY-025.justification: Further research strongly indicates these patterns are present not just in infants but also in children and adults. In the 1980s, analogues of these patterns were discovered in adults with similar relational characteristics adapted to adult contexts.
PSY-025.theoretical_significance: Establishes longitudinal stability of attachment patterns; shows early-life attachments have lasting effects on adult relationship capacity

PSY-026.title: Attachment Insecurities Linked to Specific Psychopathologies
PSY-026.statement: Attachment insecurities of both anxious and avoidant varieties are associated with depression, anxiety disorders, OCD, PTSD, suicidal tendencies, and eating disorders. Anxious attachment specifically associates with dependent, histrionic, and borderline disorders, while avoidant attachment associates with schizoid and avoidant disorders.
PSY-026.justification: There is extremely strong empirical evidence (Mikulincer & Shaver 2012, Kernberg 1984b) that inadequate early-life attachments give rise not only to maladaptive personality traits but to full-blown psychopathology. The patterns of association between attachment types and specific disorders are empirical facts.
PSY-026.theoretical_significance: Establishes empirical link between attachment patterns and specific mental illnesses; provides diagnostic and etiological framework for psychopathology

PSY-027.title: Kuczynski's Explanation of Attachment-Psychopathology Connections
PSY-027.statement: According to Kuczynski (2012), schizoid and psychotic disorders involve scrambling of the subject's grasp of reality itself because early-life attachments were negative (not merely ambiguous), disposing them to flee from reality in the most radical way possible. By contrast, histrionic, borderline, and dependent disorders involve fundamentally non-delusive grasp of reality but inappropriate emotions because early-life attachments were ambivalent, disposing them to keep distance from external reality without altogether abandoning it.
PSY-027.justification: OCD, PTSD, and eating disorders all involve fear- or trauma-driven self-isolation. The obsessive-compulsive is the quintessential loner hiding from the world and own emotions behind irrational fantasy-based obsessions. Anxious-ambivalent early attachments dispose people to deal with trauma by withdrawing rather than connecting with others.
PSY-027.theoretical_significance: Provides causal mechanism explaining why different attachment types produce different disorder categories; distinguishes reality-fleeing (psychosis) from reality-distancing (neurosis)

PSY-028.position: Psychosis is a mental impairment precipitated and sustained by a break with external reality

PSY-029.position: Neurosis is a mental impairment precipitated and sustained by a break with one's emotional condition

PSY-030.position: The neurotic flees from his emotions; the psychotic flees from reality

PSY-031.position: Neurosis may lead to blunted awareness of external reality, but this is subordinate to loss of awareness of emotional condition

PSY-032.position: Psychosis may lead to disrupted understanding of emotional condition, but this is subordinate to loss of awareness of external reality

PSY-033.position: Neurosis and psychosis are not mirror images despite their symmetries

PSY-034.position: Psychosis involves a partial (not complete) regression to a condition of psychological infancy

PSY-035.position: An infant is not psychotic because the infant's psychological integration is simply that of an infant, not simultaneously adult and infant

PSY-036.position: The infant's psychological condition is integrated and healthy even though the infant's understanding of reality is more subjective and projective than the adult psychotic's

PSY-037.position: The adult psychotic has the psychological architecture of both an adult and an infant, creating two entirely distinct and incompatible ways of processing information

PSY-038.position: The psychotic does not have a unified value system or unified understanding of how to implement values, resulting in utter psychological disarray

PSY-039.position: Neurosis is about containing threats to integration by repressing them

PSY-040.position: To repress a concept is not to bury one's knowledge of it in the unconscious; it is to bury one's knowledge of its emotional valence in the unconscious

PSY-041.position: The neurotic's condition is one of relatively unimpaired intellectual awareness

PSY-042.position: The neurotic may have heightened intellectual awareness due to compensating for impoverished emotional state by hypercathecting the intellect

PSY-043.position: By stripping consciousness of emotional valences, the neurotic guarantees a hyper-stable though ossified psyche

PSY-044.position: The essence of psychosis is an inability to organize consciously experienced emotion

PSY-045.position: The essence of neurosis is an inability to have consciously experienced emotion

PSY-046.position: The psychotic is paralyzed by a superabundance of emotion; the neurotic by lack of it

PSY-047.position: For men, happiness is about forging one's own identity
PSY-047.source_section: What determines whether one is happy?

PSY-048.position: For women, happiness is about being loved
PSY-048.source_section: What determines whether one is happy?

PSY-049.position: Men are happy if they triumphed over their own fathers; women are happy if their fathers loved them
PSY-049.source_section: What determines whether one is happy?

PSY-050.position: For a man to triumph over his father is to not submit to him; it is to establish his own identity
PSY-050.source_section: What determines whether one is happy?
